title: Thompson v. S.C. Steel Erectors
description: This Workers' Compensation appeal involves cross appeals in connection with the Commission's decision to award claimant part of his request for a partial lump sum payment and associated medical costs in a lifetime benefits case.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Samuel Clint Thompson, Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        South Carolina Steel Erectors, Employer, American Interstate Insurance, Carrier, Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4109
Heard March 8, 2006 â€“ Filed May 1, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled July 5, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Thomas W. Greene, of Charleston, for Appellant-Respondent.
        Stanford E. Lacy and Suzanne C. Boulware, both of Columbia, for Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.: We are presented with cross-appeals from a workersâ€™ compensation claim filed by Samuel Clint Thompson against his employer, South Carolina Steel Erectors and its insurance carrier, American Interstate Insurance (collectively referred to as American Interstate).[1]Â  Thompson was paralyzed in a work-related accident and awarded benefits.Â  Thompson sought a partial lump sum payment from his lifetime benefits to construct a house, as well as additional payments for exercise equipment and modifications to this house necessitated by his injuries.Â  The modifications would make the proposed home habitable for a paraplegic.Â  The single commissioner awarded Thompson relief on all counts.Â  An appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission) affirmed the award of the partial lump sum payment and the funds for exercise equipment but denied the payment for the modifications.Â  The circuit court affirmed the Commission.Â  Both parties appeal.Â  We affirm the Commission to the extent it awarded Thompson relief, and we reverse the Commissionâ€™s denial of Thompsonâ€™s request for funds to modify the house to accommodate his paraplegia. 
FACTS
Thompson worked as a welder with Steel Erectors.Â  While Thompson was hanging a 3000 pound beam, its rigging broke.Â  The beam hit Thompson, knocking him to the concrete floor 30 feet below.Â  Thompson suffered a spinal cord injury resulting in paraplegia.Â  Steel Erectors admitted liability for the accident and American Interstate began paying weekly benefits of $507.34, as well as $1,000 per month to Thompsonâ€™s wife to aid with his care.Â  
Thompson is married with two children, ages five and six.Â  At the time of the accident, the Thompson family rented a home from Thompsonâ€™s uncle for $200.00 per month, well below the monthly market rate of approximately $600.00.Â  American Interstate paid approximately $35,000 for modifications to the rental home to accommodate Thompsonâ€™s special needs. 
Thompson filed a claim with the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission for total general disability with lifetime benefits based upon his paraplegia pursuant to section 42-9-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  He also requested a partial lump sum payment from his lifetime benefits for the construction of a new home for the family.Â  Thompson sought additional money to upfit the new home to render it habitable for a paraplegic.Â  
American Interstate admitted the facts of Thompsonâ€™s injury and his disability, but opposed the requests for a partial lump sum payment and other funds.Â  As the hearing commenced, American Interstate stipulated to Thompsonâ€™s entitlement to lifetime benefits under section 42-9-10.Â  
 The single commissioner awarded Thompson lifetime benefits of $507.34 per week.Â  The commissioner also ordered American Interstate to pay $150,300 as a lump sum for the new home, to be deducted from the â€œback endâ€ of Thompsonâ€™s future benefits.Â  The commissioner found he was empowered to make an award of a partial lump sum pursuant to Glover v. Suitt Construction Company, 318 S.C. 465, 458 S.E.2d 535 (1995), and Cox v. BellSouth Telecommunications, 356 S.C. 468, 589 S.E.2d 766 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied, (Apr. 7, 2005).Â  Next, the commissioner awarded Thompson $83,700.00 for upfitting the new home to accommodate his special needs.Â  Finally, the commissioner ordered American Interstate to provide therapeutic and exercise equipment prescribed by Thompsonâ€™s neurologist.[2]Â  
The Commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s partial lump sum payment award, and also found that the amount should be deducted â€œfrom the â€˜back endâ€™ of Claimantâ€™s lifetime monetary benefits.â€Â  Specifically, the Commission found the award: (1) was in the best interest of Thompson and his family; (2) represented approximately 13% of his future benefits given his life expectancy according to the South Carolina mortality tables; (3) did not constitute a hardship to American Interstate; and (4) was a reasonable amount. The Commission also affirmed the award requiring American Interstate to provide the equipment as prescribed. 
The Commission, however, reversed the single commissionerâ€™s award of $83,700 for modifications.Â  The Commission found that because American Interstate previously spent $35,000 to upfit Thompsonâ€™s rented residence, â€œ[u]p-fitting a new residence would be duplication and an abuse of discretion on the part of this Commission.â€Â  
The circuit court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s order.Â  On appeal, Thompson challenges the Commissionâ€™s denial of his request for funds for upfitting the new home, while American Interstate challenges the partial lump sum payment award.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  In a typical appeal from the Commission, we review facts based on the substantial evidence standard.Â  Under this approach, the appellate court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  The appellate court may reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Id.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act sets forth a special standard for review of lump sum payments:Â  â€œUpon a finding by the commission that a lump sum payment should be made, the burden of proof as to the abuse of discretion in such finding shall be upon the employer or carrier in any appeal proceedings.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-301 (1985).Â  Therefore, we review the partial lump sum award for an abuse of discretion.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs if the Commissionâ€™s findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by an error of law.Â  Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 398, 520 S.E.2d 142, 155 (1999).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Thompson appeals the Commissionâ€™s denial of his request for the funds needed to upfit the new home to accommodate his paraplegia.Â  American Interstateâ€™s cross-appeal raises numerous issues challenging the partial lump sum payment award, payment for the prescribed equipment, and the requirement that the lump sum payment be deducted from the â€œback endâ€ of Thompsonâ€™s lifetime benefits.Â  We first consider American Interstateâ€™s appeal.
I.
American Interstateâ€™s Appeal
A.Â Partial Lump Sum Award 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  American Interstate contends the Commission erred in awarding Thompson a partial lump sum payment from his lifetime benefits.Â  It maintains the award: (1) should not be permitted until Thompson has been conclusively determined to be totally and permanently disabled; (2) is prohibited by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act; and (3) is not in Thompsonâ€™s best interest.Â  
1.Â Â Finding of Disability
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Section 42-9-10 governs the payment of workersâ€™ compensation benefits for total disability.Â  It allows â€œany person determined to be totally and permanently disabled who as a result of a compensable injury is a paraplegic, . . . [to] receive the benefits for life.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-10 (Supp. 2005).Â Â Â  
American Interstate contends the Commission erred in awarding a partial lump sum from Thompsonâ€™s lifetime benefits when it has not been conclusively proven that Thompson is entitled to lifetime benefits.Â  This issue is not preserved for review on appeal, as it was not raised before the Commission or the circuit court.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Not only did American Interstate fail to challenge Thompsonâ€™s entitlement to lifetime benefits, American Interstate stipulated to Thompsonâ€™s entitlement to the lifetime benefits award at the hearing before the single commissioner:

  Thompsonâ€™s Counsel:Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  First of all, since . . . thereâ€™s not a contest about this Iâ€™m sure, but since thereâ€™s no order in place confirming Mr. Thompsonâ€™s entitlement to lifetime benefits under [42-9-10] by reason of the fact that he is a paraplegic as a result of his job accident, Iâ€™d like any order . . . to establish that for the record . . . . 
  American Interstateâ€™s Counsel:Â Â Â  We can address that now.Â  We wonâ€™t have an objection to that.
  . . . .
  American Interstateâ€™s Counsel:Â Â Â  Weâ€™ll stipulate to that.
  Commissioner:Â Â  So stipulated.Â  

Because American Interstate stipulated to the award of lifetime benefits under section 42-9-10, it may not complain about the award on appeal.Â  â€œA stipulation is an agreement, admission or concession made in judicial proceedings by the parties thereto or their attorneys.Â  Stipulations, of course, are binding upon those who make them.â€Â  Kirkland v. Allcraft Steel Co., Inc., 329 S.C. 389, 392, 496 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1998) (citations omitted).Â  
2.Â  Partial Lump Sum Payment from Lifetime Benefits
American Interstate next maintains the payment of a partial lump sum from Thompsonâ€™s lifetime benefits award violates section 42-9-10 and is impossible to calculate or liquidate because it is contingent upon his survival.Â  
Section 42-9-301 empowers the Commission to order lump sum payments:

  Whenever any weekly payment has been continued for not less than six weeks, the liability therefor may, when the employee so requests and the commission deems it not to be contrary to the best interest of the employee or his dependents, or when it will prevent undue hardship on the employer or his insurance carrier, without prejudicing the interest of the employee or his dependents, be redeemed, in whole or in part, by the payment by the employer of a lump sum which shall be fixed by the commission . . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-301 (1985).Â  However, section 42-9-10 provides:Â  â€œNotwithstanding the provisions of Â§ 42-9-301, no total lump sum payment may be ordered by the commission in any case under this section where the injured person is entitled to lifetime benefits.â€ (Emphasis added).
In Glover v. Suitt Construction Company, our supreme court determined that section 42-9-10 does not prohibit recovery of attorneyâ€™s fees in a partial lump sum payment from a claimantâ€™s lifetime benefits.Â  318 S.C. 465, 469-70, 458 S.E.2d 535, 538 (1995).Â  The court noted:Â  

  Employer contends our interpretation of Â§ 42-9-10 will permit the Commission to order partial lump sum benefits to a claimant awarded lifetime benefits, a result clearly not intended by the legislature.Â  The sole issue presently before this Court is lump sum payment of attorneyâ€™s fees and, accordingly, we decline to address Employerâ€™s contention.Â  In any event, if, as Employer suggests, the statute and Regulation may be so construed, the matter is one for the General Assembly.

Id. at 470 n.4, 458 S.E.2d at 538 n.4 (emphasis in original). 
The court in Glover reasoned that the contingent nature of lifetime benefitsâ€”the fact they are only paid during the life of the claimantâ€”should not prohibit the award of a partial lump sum for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Id. at 469-70, 458 S.E.2d at 538.Â  The court explained that â€œthe mortality tables provide an adequate basis upon which to determine the present day value.â€Â  Id. at 467 n.3, 458 S.E.2d at 537 n.3.
This court had occasion to specifically address the question before us today, that is, whether section 42-9-10â€™s prohibition against a â€œtotal lump paymentâ€ from the injured personâ€™s lifetime benefits precludes partial lump sum payments of lifetime benefits.Â  Cox v. Bellsouth Telecomms., 356 S.C. 468, 589 S.E.2d 766 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied, (Apr. 7, 2005).Â  In Cox, we held this provision was â€œnot intend[ed] to prohibit partial lump sum payments of lifetime benefits.â€Â Â  Cox, 356 S.C. at 472, 589 S.E.2d at 768 (emphasis in original).Â  We stated that â€œ[p]ermitting partial lump sum payments provides the commission needed flexibility in lifetime benefits cases, flexibility it regularly exercises with respect to all other compensation awards, to ensure the best interests of the injured worker are protected.â€Â  Id. at 472-73, 589 S.E.2d at 768-69.
We discern no reason to deviate from this courtâ€™s prior holding allowing partial lump sum payments to lifetime benefits recipients.Â  As found in Cox:Â  â€œHad the General Assembly desired to eliminate all lump sum payments in lifetime benefits cases, it could have omitted the word â€˜totalâ€™ from the provision, or it could have specifically provided that â€˜allâ€™ lump sum payments were prohibited.â€Â  Id. at 472, 589 S.E.2d at 768.[3]
We hold the Commission was empowered to award a partial lump sum payment from Thompsonâ€™s lifetime monetary benefits award.[4]Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
3.Â Â Best Interest of Thompson
American Interstate next contends the payment of the lump sum award is not in the best interest of Thompson or his family.Â  We find the Commission did not abuse its discretion in making the award to Thompson.
In determining whether to award a lump sum payment to a claimant, the Commission must consider whether the award will cause a hardship to the employer or carrier and whether the payment would be in the best interest of the claimant and his family.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-301 (1985).Â  â€œUpon a finding by the commission that a lump sum payment should be made, the burden of proof as to the abuse of discretion in such finding shall be upon the employer or carrier in any appeal proceedings.â€Â  Id.
The Thompsons were living in the uncleâ€™s rental home to save money, in hopes of ultimately purchasing their own home.Â  The rental home was not intended to be a permanent home for the Thompsons.Â  The Thompsons had saved approximately $8,000 at the time of the accident.Â  Further, there is evidence supporting the view that by moving to an adjoining county, the Thompson children would attend better schools.Â  American Interstate provides no evidence indicating the award would be detrimental to Thompson or his family.Â  
We find the record supports the Commissionâ€™s determination that American Interstate failed to provide credible evidence to show the funds would be squandered or that the purpose for which Thompson sought the funds was wasteful or unreasonable.Â  We conclude there is ample evidence to support the finding that a partial lump sum award is in Thompsonâ€™s best interest.Â  We affirm the finding that Thompson is entitled to lifetime benefits, that the Commission has authority to order the partial lump sum from this award for construction of the new home, and that American Interstate has failed to demonstrate that the Commission abused its discretion.Â Â  
B.Â Â Deduction from the â€œBack Endâ€ 
American Interstate contends the Commission erred in finding the partial lump sum payment should be deducted from the â€œback endâ€ of Thompsonâ€™s lifetime monetary benefits award.Â  This issue is not properly preserved for review on appeal.Â  
American Interstate raised the issue as an exception to the Commission in its appeal from the single commissionerâ€™s ruling.Â  However, the Commission never specifically addressed the issue of â€œhow . . . payments are to be â€˜deducted from the back endâ€™ as stated in the single commissionerâ€™s order.â€Â  The Commission simply reiterated the requirement that the partial lump sum be deducted from the â€œback endâ€ of Thompsonâ€™s lifetime benefits.Â  This reference fails to show that the Commission made a ruling sufficient for preservation.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding an issue was not preserved for appellate review when the trial court did not explicitly rule on the appellantâ€™s argument).Â  Beyond this, nothing in the record demonstrates the issue was raised to the circuit court on appeal.Â  See, e.g., United Dominion Realty Trust, Inc. v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 307 S.C. 102, 107, 413 S.E.2d 866, 869 (Ct. App. 1992) (finding that when the circuit court sitting in an appellate capacity does not address an issue and the party makes no motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the alleged error is not preserved for further appellate review).Â Â  
C.Â Â Exercise and Therapeutic Equipment
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  American Interstateâ€™s final contention is that the Commission erred in requiring it to provide the equipment prescribed by Thompsonâ€™s doctor.Â  This issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  The circuit court found the award to be law of the case, specifically stating:

  The Single Commissioner ordered, [and] the Commission on Appeal sustained[,] [the finding that] â€œ[t]he Employer shall provide or cause to be provided the exercise equipment and aquatic therapy prescribed by Dr. Bailey[.]â€Â  The Full Commission upheld this provision of [the single commissionerâ€™s] order.Â  [American Interstateâ€™s] Specifications of Error do not take exception to this portion of the Order and, therefore, it is the law of the case.Â  [American Interstate] must provide this equipment.Â  

Finding nothing in the record to the contrary, we affirm this portion of the circuit courtâ€™s order pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.
II.
Thompsonâ€™s AppealÂ Â  
A.Â Â Refusal to Award Modifications to New Home
Thompson asserts the Commission erred in denying his request for the funds needed to upfit the new home to accommodate his special needs.Â  We agree.
Initially, we address the applicable standard of review for this award. The initial award by the single commissioner for the upfit to the new home expressly provided that the â€œcost of these construction features shall not be deducted from Claimantâ€™s monetary benefits.â€Â  Because the Commission cited an abuse of discretion standard when addressing the request for funds to upfit the home, it appears the Commission considered this request as one for a partial lump sum award.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-301.Â  Here, however, the amount for the upfit, while a lump sum in common parlance, is not part of (and is not to be deducted from) the benefits award.Â  The statutory abuse of discretion standard, therefore, may not be applicable on this issue.Â  Review of the Commissionâ€™s decision here may fall under the general substantial evidence standard.Â  We need not resolve this standard of review question, for we find the Commission committed legal errorâ€”the Commissionâ€™s decision may not be sustained under either standard of review.Â  We conclude that the Commission erred as a matter of law in awarding the lump sum payment for construction of the home, yet refusing to award funds sufficient to upfit the home to meet Thompsonâ€™s special needs resulting from his paraplegia.Â  See Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 398, 520 S.E.2d 142, 155 (1999) (holding that an abuse of discretion occurs if the trial courtâ€™s findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or its conclusions are controlled by an error of law); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œOn appeal from the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, the court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.â€).Â  
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act authorizes the Commission to order an employer to pay for reasonably necessary medical costs.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985).Â  The contractorâ€™s estimate specifies that the $83,700 includes the cost of necessary accommodations such as a handicapped-accessible shower and bath, wider halls and door openings, and handicap ramps.Â  Additionally, it includes building modifications necessary for the exercise and therapeutic equipment.Â  The modifications are necessitated solely by Thompsonâ€™s admittedly compensable injury.Â  The bottom line is that Thompson cannot live in the proposed home without the modifications to accommodate his paraplegia.Â  Under these circumstances, the effort by the Commission to â€œsplit the babyâ€ cannot stand.Â  Because neither the new home nor the exercise equipment would benefit Thompson without these additional modifications, we hold the Commission erred in denying the award to modify and upfit the proposed home.
We are not unmindful that this award may involve some duplication of the previous upfit of the rental home, but this fact, standing alone, is not dispositive.Â  Moreover, while we acknowledge the understandable opposition of an employer or insurance carrier to the prospect of paying for multiple moves, the present posture of this case does not warrant those concerns.Â  The result we reach today is influenced by two factors.Â  
First, the Thompsons never intended to reside permanently in the uncleâ€™s rental home.Â  Prior to Thompsonâ€™s disabling injury, the family planned to move to a permanent home, a move that would be in response to the best interests of the Thompson children, particularly their education.Â  That move was to be accomplished through Thompsonâ€™s income from work and family savings, as evidenced by the $8,000 saved as of the time of the accident.Â  The devastating blow of Thompsonâ€™s paraplegia should not be compounded by a legal decree that would effectively preclude the dream of home ownership.Â  It would be unreasonable to expect the Thompsons to live permanently in the uncleâ€™s rental home and completely abandon their hopes for some semblance of a normal life.Â  
Second, American Interstateâ€™s claim of â€œduplicationâ€ is only partially true, for substantial additional modifications to the uncleâ€™s rental home would be required were the Thompsons to remain there.Â  The contractor who performed the original modifications to the Thompsonsâ€™ rental home indicated that between $37,750 and $39,250 in further modifications would be necessary for the installation and use of the prescribed exercise and therapy equipment.Â  American Interstate knew at the time of the prior upfit to the rental home that the Thompsons could not be expected to remain there for the rest of their lives.Â  Accordingly, we reverse this portion of the Commissionâ€™s order and reinstate the award of $83,700 for upfitting the new home. 
CONCLUSION
We hold the Commission did not abuse its discretion in awarding Thompson a partial lump sum payment from his lifetime benefits award.Â  We additionally affirm the Commissionâ€™s award of the exercise equipment and therapy equipment.Â  We reverse the Commissionâ€™s denial of Thompsonâ€™s request for the funds necessary to upfit the new home.Â  The decision of the Commission is
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur. 

[1] Appellate counsel for South Carolina Steel Erectors and American Interstate did not represent Respondents-Appellants before the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission or in the circuit court.
[2] Â Neither the upfitting award nor the funds for the therapeutic and exercise equipment are to be deducted from Thompsonâ€™s lifetime benefits. 
[3] Â American Interstate argues that the supreme court has effectively reversed our Cox precedent in Stone v. Roadway Express, 367 S.C. 575, 627 S.E.2d 695 (2006).Â  In Stone, the court held that an employeeâ€™s widow is not entitled to continue receiving benefits after the employeeâ€™s death when the employee was receiving compensation under the first paragraph of section 42-9-10.Â  Id. at 586, 627 S.E.2d at 700.Â  The holding in Stone is grounded in a statute that governs the â€œpayment of the unpaid balance of compensationâ€ when the employee dies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-280 (1985).Â  Section 42-9-280 permits the payment of the unpaid balance of compensation to the â€œnext of kin dependentâ€ when the compensation was â€œfor an injury covered by the second paragraph of Â§ 42-9-10 or Â§ 42-9-30.â€Â  Stone has no application here, for Thompson is receiving lifetime benefits, and there is no claim of entitlement by a third party to Thompsonâ€™s benefits.Â  We believe the holding in Coxâ€”authorizing the Commission under Â§ 42-9-10 to award partial lump sum payments of lifetime benefitsâ€”remains binding precedent on this court.Â  
[4] Â American Interstateâ€™s policy argumentsâ€”that allowing a partial lump sum payment is tantamount to creating a life insurance account or a savings account for the claimantâ€”were not specifically raised to nor ruled on by the Commission and are not preserved for our review on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).

title: Fast Photo v. First National Bank of Chicago
description: The Specters appeal the master-in-equity's order transferring property in partial satisfaction of a judgment.  They argue: Respondent did not have standing to maintain the supplemental action against them; Respondents did not take possession of the property prior to the expiration of the judgment;  Respondents' attorney did not have authority to bring the action, and the master erred in issuing a restraining order after the judgment had expired.  We affirm in part and reverse in part.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
A Fast Photo Express, Inc., f/k/a Devine Street Camera, Inc., d/b/a American Fast Photo & Camera, Jay Specter, and Barbara Specter,
Plaintiff,
v.
First National Bank of Chicago, M.P.H. Holdings, Inc., Thomas J. Russell and John Doe,
Defendants,
AND
M.P.H. Holdings, Inc., Third-Party Plaintiff,
v.
Barbara Specter, Third-Party Defendant.
M.P.H. Holdings, Inc., Respondent,
v.
Jay Specter and Barbara Specter, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 4110
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed May 8, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART
AND REVERSED IN PART 


  
    
      
Jay and Barbara Specter, both of Columbia, Pro Se, for Appellants.
Suzanne Taylor Graham Grigg, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Jay and Barbara Specter appeal the master-in-equityâ€™s order transferring property in partial satisfaction of a judgment.[1]Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.[2]
FACTS
On September 30, 1994, M.P.H. Holdings, Inc., obtained a personal judgment against Jay and Barbara Specter for $62,730, and a writ of execution was filed on March 20, 1996.Â  An attempt was made to execute the judgment, but the sheriffâ€™s office returned the execution against property to the clerk marked â€œnulla bonaâ€ on August 14, 1996.Â  M.P.H. Holdings dissolved in 2002, and it surrendered its authority to do business in South Carolina.Â  
In the summer of 2002, Jay Specter inherited one-fifth of the personal property from his fatherâ€™s estate, and his portion of the personal property was valued at $31,000.[3]Â  On August 25, 2004, the attorney for M.P.H. Holdings petitioned the master for a supplemental proceeding in an attempt to execute the judgment.Â  Accompanying the petition was an affidavit from the attorney alleging that she was the attorney for petitioner M.P.H. Holdings.Â  The master issued a rule to show cause and scheduled a hearing. 
A hearing was held on September 23, 2004, to determine whether the Specters had any assets that could be used to satisfy the judgment.Â  Jay Specter initially appeared with counsel, but counsel was relieved during the hearing after revealing a conflict of interest.Â  The attorney who had filed the request for supplemental proceedings on behalf of M.P.H. Holdings informed the court that the corporationâ€™s assets were transferred to its successor in interest, Bank One, and she was authorized to execute the judgment on behalf of Bank One.[4]Â  During the hearing, Jay Specter asserted his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination in response to every question asked of him, and he requested a continuance in order to obtain new counsel.Â  M.P.H. Holdings provided evidence of the $31,000 in assets Specter inherited from his fatherâ€™s estate.Â Â Â  
The master granted M.P.H. Holdingsâ€™ request to execute judgment as to the $31,000 Specter inherited, and he also granted Specterâ€™s request for a continuance.Â  An order was signed by the master and filed on September 23, 2004, directing the personal representative of Specterâ€™s fatherâ€™s estate to distribute Jay Specterâ€™s interest in the personal property to M.P.H. Holdings.Â  The order further directed that any property owned by the Specters, above any homestead exemption, should be transferred.Â  The Specters filed a notice of appeal from the September 23, 2004 order on September 27, 2004.Â  
On September 28, 2004, the continued matter was heard before the master, and the Specters appeared pro se.Â  The attorneys for M.P.H. Holdings requested that the master issue a supplemental order transferring title of two cars in the Spectersâ€™ possession.Â  The master declined to issue an order transferring title of the two cars pending disposition of the appeal.Â  However, the master restrained the Specters from disposing of the cars.Â  The written order, entitled â€œOrder Restraining Damage, Concealment, Transfer, or Removal of Property,â€ was filed November 3, 2004.Â  The Specters filed a motion to reconsider this order on November 8, 2004.Â  Nothing in the record indicates this motion has ever been heard or ruled upon.Â  Further, the Specters have not filed a notice of appeal from the November 3, 2004 restraining order.Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSupplementary proceedings are equitable in nature.â€Â  Ag-Chem Equip. Co. v. Daggerhart, 281 S.C. 380, 383, 315 S.E.2d 379, 381 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In an equitable matter referred to a master for final judgment with direct appeal to the supreme court, the appellate court may determine the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Friarsgate, Inc., v. First Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n, 317 S.C. 452, 456, 454 S.E.2d 901, 904 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The appellate court is not required, however, to disregard the findings of the master.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Preservation (Issues 2, 3, and 4)
The Specters argue the master erred in ordering the transfer of Jay Specterâ€™s interest in his fatherâ€™s estate because:Â  (1) M.P.H. Holdings should not have been allowed to bring the action to examine the Specters if it sold or transferred its interest in the judgment; (2) M.P.H. Holdings failed to take possession of Jay Specterâ€™s interest in his fatherâ€™s estate prior to the September 30, 2004 expiration of the judgment; and (3) it was error for the master to issue the November 8, 2004 restraining order more than thirty days after the expiration of the judgment as an attempt to extend the judgment past the ten-year deadline.Â  These arguments are not preserved for appellate review.Â Â  
 A.Â  Transfer of M.P.H. Holdingsâ€™ Interest
The Specters argue that it was error for the master to allow M.P.H. Holdings to bring an action to examine them if it transferred its interest in the judgment to Bank One.
Before he was relieved due to a conflict of interest, the Spectersâ€™ attorney argued at the September 23, 2004 hearing that the action could not properly be brought because it was not clear who was bringing the action, there was a question concerning whether M.P.H. Holdings had standing to bring the action as a dissolved corporation, and there was a question concerning whether the action had been authorized.Â  The master overruled the objection.Â  No arguments were raised concerning whether M.P.H. Holdings could still maintain an action in its name after transferring its assets, and the master did not address this question in his order.Â  Further, the Specters failed to raise this issue in a motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Because this issue was not raised to or ruled upon by the master, it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (noting that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review).
 B. Failure to take possession prior to expiration of the judgment
The Specters assert the judgment against them has now expired, and thus, M.P.H. Holdings is not now entitled to distribution of the proceeds from Jay Specterâ€™s fatherâ€™s estate.
Judgments are enforced through writs of execution.Â  Rule 69, SCRCP.Â  Executions may issue upon a final judgment â€œat any time within ten years from the date of the original entry thereof.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-30 (2005); see Home Port Rentals, Inc. v. Moore, 359 S.C. 230, 234, 597 S.E.2d 810, 812 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting that the statutory ten-year enforcement period cannot be tolled, and thus the judgment is â€œutterly extinguishedâ€ ten years from the date of the entry of judgment), cert. granted (Sept. 22, 2005). 
The Specters are correct in asserting that the ten-year enforcement period expired on September 30, 2004.Â  However, the master issued an order on September 23, 2004, directing the personal representative of Paul Specterâ€™s estate to distribute Jay Specterâ€™s interest to M.P.H. Holdings.Â  The Specters filed their notice of appeal on September 27, 2004.Â  Thus, the order transferring Specterâ€™s inheritance and the Spectersâ€™ notice of appeal were both filed prior to the expiration of the judgment.Â  The issue of whether the judgment had expired was never raised to the master prior to the filing of the Spectersâ€™ appeal.Â  Thus, this matter is being raised for the first time on appeal.Â  Because the issue was not raised to or ruled upon by the master, it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546.
 C. November 8, 2004 restraining order
The Specters argue the duration of the judgment could not have been extended by the November 8, 2004 restraining order because it was filed over thirty days after the September 30, 2004 expiration of the judgment.Â  Thus, they argue, it was error for the master to issue the restraining order, and the order should be â€œcancelled.â€Â  
The Spectersâ€™ notice of appeal, filed September 27, 2004, indicates they were only appealing from the masterâ€™s September 23, 2004 order.Â  Therefore, any concerns regarding the November 8, 2004 restraining order are not before this court.Â  Further, the record does not indicate that the issue of whether the restraining order would improperly extend the duration of the judgment was ever raised before or ruled upon by the master.Â  Because this issue is raised for the first time on appeal, it is not properly preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546.
II. Standing (Issue 1)
The Specters argue it was improper for M.P.H. Holdings, a dissolved corporation, to maintain the supplemental action in South Carolina against them because it no longer had a certificate of authority from the Secretary of State.Â  
Foreign corporations seeking to conduct business in this state must obtain a certificate of authority from the Secretary of State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-15-103 (1990 & Supp. 2004) (outlining the procedures for obtaining a certificate of authority); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-15-105(a) (1990) (noting that a certificate of authority allows a foreign corporation to transact business in this state).Â  A foreign corporation may withdraw from conducting business in this state by obtaining a certificate of withdrawal from the Secretary of State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-15-200 (1990).Â  However, corporations that do not have a certificate of authority may not initiate proceedings in the courts of this state until a certificate of authority is obtained.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-15-102(a), (e) (1990) (noting that a foreign corporation may not initiate a judicial proceeding in this state without a certificate of authority, but this requirement does not prevent a foreign corporation from defending an action in this state).Â  Nevertheless, a dissolved corporation may continue to conduct limited business as necessary to collect its assets.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-105(a)(1) (1990) (â€œA dissolved corporation continues its corporate existence but may not carry on any business except that appropriate to wind up and liquidate its business affairs, including . . . collecting its assets . . . .â€).Â  Dissolved corporations must wind up business affairs as â€œexpeditiously as possible.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-105 (b) (1990).
M.P.H. Holdings applied to surrender its authority to do business in South Carolina on June 28, 2002.Â  The corporation also issued its certificate of dissolution on July 30, 2002.Â  M.P.H. initiated the supplemental proceeding on August 25, 2004, two years after dissolution.Â  Nothing in the record indicates that M.P.H. Holdings applied for another certificate of authority.Â  
At the September 23rd hearing, the Spectersâ€™ attorney raised issues before the master concerning:Â  (1) whether the supplemental proceeding could be properly brought by M.P.H. Holdings, a dissolved corporation; (2) whether Bank One had standing where there was no indication that it was assigned M.P.H. Holdingsâ€™ assets; or (3) whether the filing attorney had any authority to bring the supplemental action.Â  In arguing the issue of whether M.P.H. Holdings had standing as a dissolved corporation to bring the action, the Spectersâ€™ attorney noted that South Carolina law provides dissolved corporations cannot bring actions in the state.Â  The attorney submitted copies of the surrender of authority, and he noted that no one had made an application for a certificate of authority.Â  The master noted that dissolved corporations could conduct business to collect their assets.Â  The master later overruled the attorneyâ€™s objections just prior to relieving him from his representation of the Specters due to a conflict.Â  The master did not address whether M.P.H. Holdings had standing to bring the supplemental action or whether M.P.H. Holdings could maintain the action without a certificate of authority in the September 23, 2004 written order.
Initially, we note this issue appears to be preserved.Â  Although the master referred to section 33-14-105 in his discussions with the attorneys, the Spectersâ€™ attorney continued to argue the standing issue and specifically noted that no one had made an application for a certificate of authority.Â  The master overruled the objections.Â  Thus, despite the fact that the issue was not addressed by the written order, the issue was raised to and ruled upon by the master.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546 (noting that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court in order to be preserved for appellate review). 
As to the merits, we are troubled by the lack of evidence in the record regarding the authority of M.P.H. Holdings to initiate the supplemental proceedings.Â  A plain reading of section 33-15-102(a) requires a foreign corporation to have a certificate of authority prior to initiating any action in this state.Â  See Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (â€œWhere the statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€); see also Chet Adams Co. v. James F. Pederson Co., 307 S.C. 33, 37, 413 S.E.2d 827, 829 (1992) (holding the failure of a foreign corporation to obtain a certificate of authority prior to bringing an action to recover monies owed on an account affected the corporationâ€™s capacity to sue but did not affect the courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction).Â  Although the master referred to section 33-14-105 as allowing a dissolved corporation to pursue its assets, nothing in that section appears to indefinitely relieve a dissolved foreign corporation from obtaining a certificate of authority prior to bringing actions in South Carolina courts pursuant to section 33-15-102(a).Â  Because there was no evidence in the record that M.P.H. Holdings applied for another certificate of authority in order to initiate the supplemental proceedings, we agree with the Specters that the master erred in failing to find M.P.H. Holdings did not have standing to bring the underlying action.[5]
Further, we do not believe the action could have been properly maintained by Bank One, the alleged successor in interest.Â  Certainly, a successor in interest may maintain a supplemental action to examine a judgment debtor in order to execute a judgment.Â  See Rule 69, SCRCP (allowing a judgment creditor, or the â€œsuccessor in interest when that interest appears of record,â€ to examine judgment debtors in aid of execution of a judgment).Â  However, the supplemental proceeding below was filed in the name of M.P.H. Holdings, not Bank One, no documents were produced evidencing that Bank One was the successor in interest, and nothing was produced to show that Bank One had a certificate of authority to bring an action in South Carolina.Â  Moreover, section 33-15-102(a) would prohibit a successor in interest from maintaining an action without obtaining a certificate of authority.Â  
Although M.P.H. Holdingsâ€™ attorney asserted to the master that Bank One was the successor in interest, was the real entity bringing the action, and had a certificate of authority, there was no evidence presented to support these assertions.Â  We find there was no evidence of record to support a finding that Bank One was the successor in interest with authority to initiate the supplemental proceedings below.Â  Accordingly, the master erred in issuing the September 24, 2004 order.
III.Â  Attorney Authority (Issue 5)
The Specters argue that a law firm or its associates may not â€œbring an action . . . on behalf of a dissolved corporation that they knew was dissolved and then at trial claim that they . . . were representing a third party not mentioned or referenced in the Petition or accompanying Affidavit . . . .â€Â Â  
As discussed above, the attorneyâ€™s affidavit filed in support of the underlying action alleged that she was the attorney for M.P.H. Holdings, the petitioner, in the request for the supplemental proceedings.Â  Prior to being relieved, the Spectersâ€™ attorney objected to going forward with the action merely on the representation of an attorney that there was an assignment of the judgment to Bank One.Â  The Spectersâ€™ attorney argued the action could not go forward because M.P.H. Holdings was a dissolved corporation and there was no evidence of an assignment.Â  The master overruled the objection.Â Â Â  
There is nothing in the record showing that Bank One was a successor in interest to this action or that the attorney represented Bank One.Â  Thus, the record before us would indicate that the attorney filed the matter without authority from a client.Â  See Dunkley v. Shoemate, 515 S.E.2d 442, 445 (N.C. 1999) (finding the trial court erred in allowing a law firm to represent a client in a matter where the firm had no contact with the client and had not been authorized by the client to act on his behalf).Â  Accordingly, we find the master erred in issuing the September 24, 2004 order when there was no indication that the moving attorney had proper authority to bring the action. 
CONCLUSION
There is no evidence in the record before us showing that M.P.H. Holdings had a certificate of authority to bring the underlying supplemental action, no evidence showing that Bank One was the successor in interest to M.P.H. Holdings with a certificate of authority to bring the action, and no evidence that the attorney was authorized to bring the supplemental proceedings.Â  Accordingly, the master erred in issuing the September 24, 2004 order.Â  The masterâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
 HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.

[1]Â  Respondent M.P.H. Holdings has not filed a final brief in this case. 
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  The will further instructed that the house in which Jay and Barbara lived, valued at over $200,000, and any remainder of the $1,000,000 estate should be placed in the â€œJay M. Specter Trust.â€Â  
[4]Â  The master overruled Specterâ€™s objection that Bank One did not have standing to file the supplemental proceedings to enforce M.P.H. Holdingsâ€™ judgment.Â  Because the standing question is also an issue on appeal, we will continue to refer to the moving party in the underlying supplemental proceedings as â€œM.P.H. Holdingsâ€ in accordance with the caption.Â Â  
[5] Despite the masterâ€™s reliance on section 33-14-105(a) as allowing a dissolved corporation to wind up its affairs, we note that the two year delay before M.P.H. Holdings brought the underlying action does not comport with the statutory mandate that winding up shall be accomplished as â€œexpeditiously as possible.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-105(b) (1990).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        LandBank Fund VII, LLC., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kent D. Dickerson, Dickerson & Sons, Inc., and Phoenix Land and Development Company, LLC, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. Â 4111
Heard March 7, 2006 â€“ Filed May 8, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled July 11, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        C. Mitchell Brown, William C. Wood, Jr., Elizabeth Herlong Campbell, all of Columbia, for Appellants.
        J. Jackson Thomas, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Kent D. Dickerson, Dickerson & Sons, Inc., and Phoenix Land and Development Company, LLC,[1] appeal a decision of the Horry County Master-in-Equity concluding Dickerson was not entitled to additional compensation for certain work performed on behalf of LandBank Fund VII, LLC.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1995, Joe C. Garrell, a Myrtle Beach resident and licensed realtor, recruited investors from among his family and friends for the purpose of acquiring and reselling a large tract of land in Horry County.Â  The group of investors formed LandBank, LLC, a South Carolina limited liability company, to facilitate the transaction.Â  Garrell received a real estate commission on the land sale and a membership interest in the company for his efforts in forming the entity and acquiring the land.
 The initial LandBank transaction proceeded smoothly and was financially beneficial to the company and its members.Â  Accordingly, the transaction was followed by several other purchases, most from the same seller as the initial transaction, International Paper. To facilitate these subsequent purchases, four additional limited liability companies were formed.Â  The companies were ultimately dubbed Landbank II, LandBank Fund III, LandBank Fund IV, and Landbank Fund V.Â  LandBank entities II through V were each concerned with separate purchases, and the subsequent sale of, different tracts of land, but were virtually identical in membership and operation to the original LandBank, LLC.
In 1999, LandBank Resource Management, LLC, (â€œLRMâ€) was formed to provide management services to all the LandBank entities.Â  According to the respondent, LRM was a board managed entity owning no property.Â  Its function was to manage the LandBank entities, review and consider additional LandBank investor opportunities, and meet the service needs of the various LandBank entities, including the procurement of surveying, engineering, land planning, legal, zoning, utilities, and environmental services.Â  LRMâ€™s operational funds came from reimbursements by the other LandBank entities.Â  Though under the direction of the LRM board, Garrell handled the day-to-day management of LRM.
In 2000, Garrell began feeling somewhat overwhelmed by the extent of his LandBank responsibilities and requested that the LRM board allow him to seek professional assistance.Â  In March 2000, Garrell engaged the professional consulting services of Dickerson, a non-practicing attorney from Arizona who was knowledgeable and experienced in the acquisition and marketing of real estate.Â  These services were initially intended to be temporary and Dickersonâ€™s agreement with LandBank anticipated completion by around September 2000.
LRM was pleased with the initial services provided by Dickerson.Â  In April 2001, Garrell, after again receiving the full consent of the LRM board, entered into a modification of Dickersonâ€™s consulting agreement.Â  In addition to the compensation called for in Dickersonâ€™s initial agreement, the modification called for a $30,000 â€œperformance based feeâ€ to be paid to Dickerson in appreciation of his prior efforts.Â  The modification also secured Dickersonâ€™s future services for an indefinite period of time, terminable upon six months notice by either party.Â  As compensation for his continued non-exclusive services, the modification called for Dickerson to receive $15,000 per month, $2,000 per month in home rental expenses, a sport utility vehicle, cell phone, computer, office, and company credit card.Â  The modification agreement also called for future â€œtransaction/performance-based compensation when justified and agreed to in advance.â€
In February 2002, Dickerson proposed a venture to the LRM board that was substantially different than LandBankâ€™s prior business activities.Â  Dickerson envisioned a â€œbeach clubâ€ concept for the benefit of the end purchasers of all the LandBank properties.Â  Because the properties were landlocked, he felt the purchase and development of a beachfront club and restaurant could be used to enhance the marketability of the LandBank properties.Â  The proposed beach club was to be acquired and developed by a separate LandBank entity, LandBank Fund VI.Â  This proposal was different from the previous LandBank entities in that it contemplated continued ownership and operation of a facility, rather than the simple acquisition, marketing, and sale of a tract of undeveloped land.
Dickerson pitched this new business concept to the LRM board on several occasions and submitted an official â€œsummary proposalâ€ in July 2002.Â  Due to the higher risk involved in this sort of business venture, the proposal was not as well received by the LandBank members as prior business opportunities.Â  In order to make LandBank Fund VI a more attractive investment for the members of the previous LandBank entities, the beach club plan (LandBank Fund VI) was coupled with a low-risk investment with a promising possibility of quick profit.Â  Named LandBank Fund VII, LLC, this business proposal was to fit the traditional mold of the LandBank through LandBank V entities.Â  It involved another purchase of a large tract of land from International Paper at $15,000 an acre and a potentially quick resell to homebuilder D.R. Horton for $20,000 an acre.Â  It was understood among the members of the prior LandBank entities that LandBank Fund VI and VII were a â€œpackage dealâ€ and membership in the lower risk LandBank Fund VII meant membership in the higher risk LandBank Fund VI.Â  Ultimately, about sixty-five percent of the LandBank members joined LandBank Fund VI and VII.
By September 2002, LandBank Fund VIIâ€™s purchase of the International Paper (â€œIPâ€) tract was under contract with Garrell.Â  The sales agreement with IP provided for the assignment of Garrellâ€™s contract rights to LandBank Fund VII prior to closing.Â  On December 6, 2002, LandBank Fund VII purchased the IP property.Â  Due largely to complications concerning environmental issues, the desired simultaneous sale to D.R. Horton was delayed.
 During several meetings leading up to the purchase of the IP tract, Dickerson did not disclose to the LRM board that, beginning as early as September 2002, he was attempting to obtain a very large â€œasset placement feeâ€ of three and one-half percent of the total D.R. Horton sales price payable to him by LandBank Fund VII upon closing.Â  According to Dickerson, this fee was openly discussed and fully approved by Garrell as early as the summer of 2002.Â  Richard Lovelace, an attorney for the LandBank entities who performed a substantial amount of work on the LandBank Fund VII transaction, supports Dickersonâ€™s claims regarding the fee, at least to the extent that the fee was discussed among Dickerson, Garrell, and himself.
Garrell does not dispute the fact that Dickersonâ€™s fee was discussed between them.Â  According to Garrell, however, he made it very clear to Dickerson that he did not have the authority to approve such a large payment and the matter would first have to be approved of by the LRM board.Â  To this end, Garrell entered Dickersonâ€™s fee by hand on a draft closing statement just before a meeting between board chairman Lyle Ray King, Dickerson and himself on January 12, 2003.Â  According to both Garrell and King, the fee was unequivocally discussed at this meeting and King told Dickerson in unmistakable terms that the proposed fee was not acceptable and would not be approved by the board.
 Dickerson claims that the fee discussions with King were â€œnon-committalâ€ and that he left the meeting believing he still had a binding agreement regarding his additional fee due to his prior discussions with Garrell.Â  Nevertheless, two days after the meeting with King, Dickerson instructed attorney Lovelaceâ€™s staff to change the signature block on all future proposed contracts with D.R. Horton to reflect that it would be signed on behalf of LandBank Fund VII by â€œKent D. Dickerson, its Representative.â€Â  Dickersonâ€™s specific written instructions concerning the signature page included the phrase â€œNo Joe Garrell or Lyle Ray King.â€
On January 20, 2003, Dickerson signed and delivered (as LandBank Fund VIIâ€™s â€œRepresentativeâ€) to D.R. Horton a contract which included the payment of the â€œasset placement and assignment feeâ€ by LandBank Fund VII to Dickerson.Â  The negotiations with D.R. Horton concerning the contractâ€™s terms were handled exclusively by Dickerson and Lovelace and finalized on January 30, 2003.Â  There is a factual dispute between the parties as to the extent Garrell was kept abreast of these negotiations, including a heated disagreement as to when he first received a draft of the contract including Dickersonâ€™s disputed fee.Â  Garrell claims he was kept in the dark as to the specific terms of the contract drafts passing between Dickerson and D.R. Horton.
On February 21, 2003, Dickerson attended a meeting of the LandBank VI and VII Board of Managers.Â  At this meeting, Dickerson discussed the imminent closing of the D.R. Horton transaction and the board reviewed a sales and cash flow analysis for the upcoming sale.Â  Conspicuously absent from this presentation was any mention of the fee sought by Dickerson.Â  
The closing of LandBank Fund VIIâ€™s sale to D.R. Horton took place on March 13, 2003.Â  According to Garrell, he received a copy of the proposed final contract approximately ten days prior to the closing date.[2]Â  Upon noticing Dickersonâ€™s fee was included in this draft, Garrell told Dickerson the fee had not been approved by the board and must be removed from the final closing statement.Â  Nevertheless, Dickersonâ€™s desired fee appeared on the closing statement prepared by Lovelace on the day of closing.Â  When Garrell noticed the fee remained in the documents, he struck Dickersonâ€™s fee from the closing statement and refused to sign until a new closing statement was prepared that did not call for the payment of Dickersonâ€™s â€œasset placement fee.â€Â  The revised closing statements were prepared and the LandBank Fund VII sale to D.R. Horton was finalized.
Dickerson continued to claim entitlement to the $373,998 fee in conjunction with the 445-acre land sale to D.R. Horton.Â  LandBank Fund VII filed a complaint on May 2, 2003, seeking a declaratory judgment that Dickerson was not owed the disputed fee.Â  Dickerson counterclaimed, asserting he was entitled to the fee based on breach of contract or, alternatively, in quantum meruit for services provided.Â  The mater was referred by consent to the Horry County Master-in-Equity.Â  By order filed July 14, 2004, the Master-in-Equity granted LandBank Fund VIIâ€™s requested relief and dismissed Dickersonâ€™s counterclaims with prejudice.Â  Dickersonâ€™s motion to alter or amend the order was denied.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
I. Breach of Contract
 An action alleging breach of contract is an action at law.Â  Airfare, Inc. v. Greenville Airport Commâ€™n, 249 S.C. 265, 269, 153 S.E.2d 846, 848 (1967); Foxfire Village, Inc. v. Black & Veatch, Inc., 304 S.C. 366, 369, 404 S.E.2d 912, 914 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  â€œIn an action at law, an appellate court will correct errors of law but must defer to the trial courtâ€™s factual findings and affirm unless there is no evidence reasonably supporting those findings.â€ Crafton v. Brown, 346 S.C. 347, 351, 550 S.E.2d 904, 905-906 (Ct. App. 2001).
 In the present case, the Master-in-Equity, after reviewing the evidence presented and considering the testimony and credibility of the witnesses, found that Dickerson â€œfailed to establish by a preponderance of the evidence that there was a meeting of the minds as to the payment of a fee or commission . . . in connection with the sale of land to D.R. Horton.â€Â  Upon review of the record on appeal, we conclude the Masterâ€™s finding is supported by the evidence.
The burden of establishing the existence of an oral contract and its terms between Dickerson and LandBank Fund VII rests upon Dickerson.Â  See Jackson v. Frier, 146 S.C. 322, 329, 144 S.E. 66, 68 (1928) (â€œThe burden is on a party pleading a fact to prove it.â€)Â  In order to establish the existence of an oral fee agreement, Dickerson must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that there was a meeting of the minds as to all of the essential and material terms of the alleged agreement.Â  See Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 104-105, 382 S.E.2d 891, 893-894 (1989).
Despite Dickersonâ€™s relative sophistication in business and legal matters, no written agreement to pay the fee signed by LandBank Fund VII was ever obtained (excluding the D.R. Horton contract signed only by Dickerson as a â€œRepresentativeâ€ of LandBank Fund VII).Â  Accordingly, the Master was confronted with highly conflicting testimony and evidence concerning the presence or absence of a verbal agreement.Â  Although Garrell does not dispute the fact that he discussed payment of the disputed fee with Dickerson as early as the summer of 2002, he maintains, and the Master-in-Equity agreed, that he made clear to Dickerson any compensation in addition to that called for in his lucrative consulting agreement with LRM could only be obtained with board approval.Â  This understanding between LandBank Fund VII and Dickerson is further bolstered by the testimony of King, the board chairman, concerning the meeting of January 12, 2003, during which King explained to Dickerson the board would not approve such a large payment.Â  Dickerson was aware Garrell first sought and received board approval in every prior dealing concerning his compensation.
Conversely, Dickersonâ€™s own evidence and testimony tend to reflect the fluid nature of his alleged â€œasset placement feeâ€ agreement.Â  In several contract drafts present in the record on appeal, the percentage fee first appears in a document dated January 13, 2003, the day after Dickerson was told of the boardâ€™s probable denial of the proposed fee.Â  All previous drafts call for either no fee, a fee paid by D.R. Horton, a fee of $2000 per acre, or a fee of an indeterminate amount.Â  The testimony of Lovelace, LandBank Fund VIIâ€™s attorney, supporting Dickersonâ€™s claims goes only as far as to back up that Dickersonâ€™s fee was, in fact, discussed among Garrell, Dickerson, and Lovelace.Â  It does not refute Garrellâ€™s claims that Dickerson was made well aware of the need for board approval before any agreement concerning additional compensation would be binding on LandBank Fund VII.Â  
If Garrell made clear to Dickerson that any fee agreement was not valid until approved by the board, then clearly no meeting of the minds occurred between Garrell and Dickerson regarding the finality of Dickersonâ€™s fee agreement, regardless of Garellâ€™s actual or apparent authority to bind LandBank Fund VII.Â  The Master-in-Equity, considering conflicting evidence, determined that Dickerson was, in fact, made aware of the necessity for board approval.Â  Accordingly, he concluded Dickerson failed to carry his burden of proof establishing a binding fee agreement between the parties.Â  Because there is evidence reasonably supporting his conclusion, we affirm the Master on this basis.[3] [4]
II. Quantum Meruit
Dickerson argues on appeal that the Master-in-Equity erred in dismissing his counterclaim for quantum meruit recovery based on Dickersonâ€™s receipt of compensation under his consulting agreement with LRM.Â  We disagree.
An action based on a theory of quantum meruit recovery sounds in equity.Â  Columbia Wholesale v. Scudder May N.V., 312 S.C. 259, 261, 440 S.E.2d 129, 130 (1994).Â  When reviewing an action in equity, an appellate court â€œreviews the evidence to determine facts in accordance with [its] own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).
In order to establish a valid claim for recovery in quantum meruit, the plaintiff must establish â€œ(1) benefit conferred by [the] plaintiff upon the defendant; (2) realization of that benefit by the defendant; and (3) retention of the benefit by the defendant under circumstances that make it inequitable for him to retain it without paying it value.â€Â  Myrtle Beach Hospital, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 8-9, 532 S.E.2d 868, 872 (2000) (emphasis added).Â  Under his modified consulting agreement, Dickerson was compensated at over $250,000 per year by LRM, the managing entity of all the LandBank companies.Â  The modified agreement secured Dickersonâ€™s service to LRM, an entity with the stated goal of considering additional LandBank investor opportunities, for an indefinite period of time.Â  Furthermore, Dickersonâ€™s consulting agreement expressly states that future â€œ[t]ransaction/performance based compensationâ€ will be granted only â€œwhen justified and agreed to in advance.â€
Considering Dickersonâ€™s lucrative contract with LRM, we agree with the Master-in-Equityâ€™s conclusions on this matter.Â  We find nothing in the record on appeal that would make recovery by Dickerson on his quantum meruit claims appropriate or equitable.Â  The fact that LandBank Fund VI and VII were not in existence when Dickerson entered his consulting contract with LRM does not persuade this court such ventures were not contemplated when Dickersonâ€™s future services were secured.
For the foregoing reasons, the Master-in-Equityâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, J.J., concur.

[1] This appeal and the underlying action involve the employment of Kent D. Dickerson, acting both individually and, in some instances, on behalf of the aforementioned companies.Â  Because the differing roles of Dickerson as both individual and head of these companies are not at issue, this opinion will collectively refer to all appealing entities as â€œDickersonâ€ for the remainder of this opinion.
[2] There is a factual dispute between the parties as to when Garrell actually received this draft of the â€œfinalâ€ contract.
[3] Because we affirm the Masterâ€™s finding that there was no meeting of the minds between Garrell and/or LandBank Fund VII and Dickerson concerning Dickersonâ€™s fee agreement, we need not address Dickersonâ€™s arguments regarding Garrellâ€™s presumptive authority to bind LandBank Fund VII.
[4] Dickerson also argues that the ultimate closing of the D.R. Horton deal by LandBank VII amounts to a ratification of the contract and, with it, Dickersonâ€™s fee.Â  This issue is wholly without merit.Â  The present appeal concerns an alleged fee agreement between Dickerson and LandBank VII, not a material term of the contract between LandBank VII and D.R. Horton.Â  It would be a gross misapplication of the ratification doctrine to conclude that Dickerson, acting unilaterally as the â€œrepresentativeâ€ of LandBank VII, is entitled to the fee because he inserted it into a contract between two other parties, notwithstanding the fact that the land sale contract was ultimately consummated.

description: W.J. â€œJoeyâ€ Douan appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Charleston County Councilâ€™s (the Council) Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion to dismiss. text:
Douan v.Charleston County Council


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
W.J. â€œJoeyâ€ Douan, Appellant,
v.
Charleston County Council and Charleston County Election Commission, Defendants,
Of whom Charleston County Council is the, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4112
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed May 22, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Thomas R. Goldstein, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Joseph Dawson, III, Bernard E. Ferrara, Jr. and Cantrell M. Frayer, all of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  W.J. â€œJoeyâ€ Douan appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Charleston County Councilâ€™s (the Council) Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion to dismiss.Â  The circuit court held Douan cannot recover attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) because his action against the Council is moot.Â  We hold the circuit court erred in dismissing Douanâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fee claim based on the doctrine of mootness.Â  We reverse and remand.
 I.
â€œA ruling on a 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss must be based solely upon the allegations set forth on the face of the complaint and the motion cannot be sustained if facts alleged and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case.â€Â  Toussaint v. Ham, 292 S.C. 415, 416, 357 S.E.2d 8, 9 (1987).Â  â€œThe question is whether in the light most favorable to plaintiff, and with every doubt resolved in his behalf, the complaint states any valid claim for relief.â€Â  Id.
II.  
In 1995, the General Assembly enacted section 4-37-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  Section 4-37-10 authorizes a county to establish a transportation authority to oversee transportation-related projects funded through sales and use taxes or tolls.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 4-37-10 & -30 (Supp. 2005).Â  If a county chooses to impose a sales and use tax, the county must enact an ordinance, and the ordinance must be accepted by the county citizenry through a referendum.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-37-30(A).Â  The question posed on the referendum ballot must substantially adhere to the model question set forth in section 4-37-30(A)(3).Â  If a majority of qualified electors answer the question in the affirmative, the sales and use tax is imposed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-37-30(A)(4).
The underlying dispute in this case arose from the Councilâ€™s enactment of an ordinance imposing a one-half percent sales and use tax to fund transportation-related projects within Charleston County.Â  To effectuate the ordinance, the Council planned to hold a referendum on November 5, 2002.Â  On October 7, Douan brought an action against the Council alleging the proposed ordinance exceeded the scope of section 4-37-30, which requires the ordinance be transportation-related.Â  Douan further alleged the proposed referendum question violated section 4-37-30(A)(3), which provides the form the question presented to the voters must take.Â  He sought a declaratory judgment, a writ of mandamus, and injunctive relief.Â  Douan further sought attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300, which allows the â€œprevailing partyâ€ of a â€œcivil actionâ€ against a State political subdivision to recover attorneyâ€™s fees. 
On October 24, the circuit court denied Douanâ€™s requests for a writ of mandamus and injunctive relief.Â  The court also declined to determine the legitimacy of the proposed referendum question, finding the issue rested in the supreme courtâ€™s exclusive jurisdiction.Â  Douan followed the lead of the circuit court and petitioned the supreme court.Â  The supreme court, however, denied his petition, rejecting the view of the circuit court that the supreme court had exclusive jurisdiction over questions prepared by the Council.Â  The exclusive jurisdiction of the supreme court is limited to questions prepared by the Ballot Commission.Â  On November 1, Douan filed a motion for reconsideration, which the circuit court summarily denied.Â  
On November 5, the referendum took place, and the proposed sales and use tax passed.Â  The next day, Douan challenged the referendum through the administrative process provided by statutory election law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 7-17-10 to -340 (1976 & Supp. 2005).Â  Douan filed an election protest with the Charleston County Election Commission (the Commission) advancing the same grounds set forth in his civil action.Â  The Commission rejected the election protest, and Douan appealed to the State Election Commission (the State Commission).Â  The State Commission deadlocked, thus affirming the Commissionâ€™s decision.
Douan appealed to the South Carolina Supreme Court, which ruled in his favor.Â  Douan v. Charleston County Council, 357 S.C. 601, 612-13, 594 S.E.2d 261, 266-67 (2003).Â  The supreme court voided the referendum results.
In the wake of the supreme court opinion, the previously filed civil action was called for trial in the Charleston County court of common pleas.Â  Douan moved the circuit court for summary judgment on the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-7-300.Â  The Council moved to dismiss the civil action on the ground of mootness pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6).Â  The circuit court denied Douanâ€™s motion, and granted the Councilâ€™s motion to dismiss, holding that the supreme court opinion ended the case in Douanâ€™s favor, rendering the claim for attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300 moot.Â  Douan appealed. 
 III.
Douan argues the circuit court erred in finding he was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300 of the South Carolina Code because his civil action was moot.Â  We agree with Douan and hold that his claim for attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300 should not have been dismissed based on the doctrine of
mootness. 
Section 15-77-300 provides:

In any civil action brought by the State, any political subdivision of the State or any party who is contesting state action, unless the prevailing party is the State or any political subdivision of the State, the court may allow the prevailing party to recover reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees to be taxed as court costs against the appropriate agency if:
(1) The court finds that the agency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim against the party; and
(2) The court finds that there are no special circumstances that would make the award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust.

The statute clearly provides that certain elements must be met to recover attorneyâ€™s fees: (1) the party seeking attorneyâ€™s fees must be the prevailing party; (2) the unsuccessful agency must have acted without substantial justification in pressing the claim against the party; and (3) there must not be special circumstances that would make an award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust.Â  City of Charleston v. Masi, 362 S.C. 505, 510, 609 S.E.2d 301, 304 (2005).Â  A â€œprevailing partyâ€ is a party who successfully prosecutes the action by prevailing on the main issue and â€œin whose favor the decision or verdict is rendered and judgment entered.â€Â  Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182-83, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990) (citing Buza v. Columbia Lumber Co., 395 P.2d 511, 514 (Alaska 1964)).Â  The key factor in determining whether a party is a prevailing party is the degree of success obtained by the party seeking attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Id. at 183, 394 S.E.2d at 711.Â  Additionally, â€œa party need not be successful as to all issues in order to be found to be a prevailing party.â€Â 
Id. at 182, 394 S.E.2d at 711; Seckinger v. The Vessel, Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 388, 483 S.E.2d 775, 778 (Ct. App. 1997).
â€œA matter becomes moot â€˜when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€™â€Â  Collins Music Co., Inc. v. IGT, 365 S.C. 544, 549, 619 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567-68, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (alterations in original)).[1]  
In our view, dismissal of Douanâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees, based on the doctrine of mootness, was improper.Â  The Council contended at oral argument that Douanâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees is essentially premature since the underlying merits of the civil action have yet to be adjudicated, a view at odds with the doctrine of mootness.Â  Indeed, Douanâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees may be addressed only after the underlying merits have been adjudicated.
Although Douan prevailed in the related administrative proceeding, we make no finding as to the preclusive effect of the supreme court opinion in this action.Â  We further make no finding as to Douanâ€™s entitlement to an award of attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300.Â  We simply hold that Douanâ€™s claim is not moot, and he is entitled to pursue his claim for relief in the civil action, specifically the request for attorneyâ€™s fees.[2]Â  
IV.
The order of the circuit court dismissing as moot Douanâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees under section 15-77-300 isÂ  
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur. 

[1]   In civil cases, there are three exceptions to the mootness doctrine: (1) an appellate court can retain jurisdiction if the issue is capable of repetition yet evading review; (2) an appellate court can decide cases of urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in matters of important public interest; and (3) if the decision by the trial court can affect future events or have collateral consequences to the parties, the appellate court can take jurisdiction.Â  Collins Music, 365 S.C. at 549, 619 S.E.2d at 3.Â  In this appeal, we do not reach an exception to the mootness doctrine, for Douanâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees is not moot.
[2]   Counsel for Douan stipulated at oral argument that the claim for attorneyâ€™s fees is limited to the civil action.
