title: Pirri v. Pirri
description: In this domestic matter, Wife appeals the family court's refusal to award her alimony, decision to find certian property was non-marital, and failure to find certain property was transmuted.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Roberta Selleck Pirri, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
John S. Pirri, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Â Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4113
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed May 22, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART
REVERSED IN PART
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Adam Fisher, Jr., of Greenville; for Appellant-Respondent.
J. P. Anderson, Jr., of Greenwood; for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this domestic cross-appeal, John Pirri (â€œHusbandâ€) argues the court erred in valuing marital property and in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Roberta Pirri (â€œWifeâ€).Â  Wife argues the court erred in failing to award her alimony, failing to find certain property was marital, and failing to find certain property was transmuted into marital property.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
Husband and Wife began living together in Connecticut in 1971.Â  They never had a ceremonial wedding.Â  However, Wife began using â€œPirriâ€ as her last name sometime in the 1970s, and the parties filed joint income tax returns from the 1970s on.Â  Husband adopted Wifeâ€™s then nineteen-year-old daughter, Julia, in 1981, and changed her name to Julia Pirri.Â  The parties referred to each other as â€œhusbandâ€ and â€œwife,â€ and Husbandâ€™s will left his estate to â€œMrs. Pirri.â€Â  
Husband was a successful veterinarian, and Wife worked in the clinic he owned from 1971 until 1978.Â  In 1978, the parties closed the veterinary clinic and converted the property to an indoor shooting range.Â  Husband and Wife continued to work at the shooting range until 1994.Â  Husband later leased the property to the Widewater hotel development corporation in 1998.Â  The parties maintained an affluent lifestyle, with joint checking accounts and investments, although Husband also had substantial investments in his own name.Â  
In 1990, the parties purchased 216 acres in Abbeville County, South Carolina, titled the property in both of their names, and built a large house upon the land.Â  They moved to South Carolina in 1996.Â  In addition to the house and acreage, Husband purchased an airplane after the parties moved to South Carolina.Â  The parties did not have any debt on these assets.Â  
The parties separated in 2002 when Wife discovered sexually explicit emails between Husband and other men.Â  Although Husband testified he was only having â€œcybersexâ€ and not actual physical encounters, Wife and the partiesâ€™ daughter, Julia, testified that Husband admitted having sexual encounters with two individuals with whom he was exchanging e-mails.Â  Wife left the home and filed the underlying action seeking:Â  a finding by the family court of a common law marriage; a divorce on the ground of adultery; equitable division of all of the marital estate; alimony; and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband counterclaimed, denying the existence of a marriage and requesting certain property and an accounting in the event the court found a marriage existed.Â  
At the beginning of the final hearing, the parties stipulated that a common law marriage existed in South Carolina.Â  Husband was also allowed to amend his pleadings to include a claim for divorce based on one year of continuous separation.Â  After hearing the evidence, the family court issued a final order declaring a common law marriage came into existence between the parties in 1996, when they moved to South Carolina.Â  The court granted Husband a divorce based upon one year of continuous separation, divided the partiesâ€™ property that was either jointly titled or obtained after 1996, denied Wifeâ€™s request for alimony, granted Wifeâ€™s request to return to the use of her maiden name, and awarded Wife $15,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The court denied the motion to alter or amend the judgment, and both Husband and Wife appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002)
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Husbandâ€™s Appeal

 A. Valuation of the Marital Home

Husband argues the family court abused its discretion in adopting Wifeâ€™s valuation of the marital home and acreage over his valuation.Â  We disagree.
In making an equitable distribution of marital property, the family court must identify real and personal marital property and determine the propertyâ€™s fair market value.Â  Cannon v. Cannon, 321 S.C. 44, 48, 467 S.E.2d 132, 134 (Ct. App. 1996); Noll v. Noll, 297 S.C. 190, 192, 375 S.E.2d 338, 340 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œIn the absence of contrary evidence, the court should accept the value the parties assign to a marital asset.â€Â  Noll, 297 S.C. at 194, 375 S.E.2d at 340-41.Â  The family court has broad discretion in valuing the marital property.Â  Roe v. Roe, 311 S.C. 471, 478, 429 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  A family court may accept the valuation of one party over another, and the courtâ€™s valuation of marital property will be affirmed if it is within the range of evidence presented.Â  Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987) (affirming the family courtâ€™s valuation of property that was within the range of evidence presented); Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 198, 363 S.E.2d 404, 407 (Ct. App. 1987) (noting that the family court is within its discretion to accept one partyâ€™s valuation over the other partyâ€™s).
There was evidence in the record to support the family courtâ€™s valuation of the marital home.Â  Both parties presented evidence regarding the value of the Abbeville County acreage and house.Â  Wife had the acreage and 4,500 square foot house appraised by Robert J. Deering.Â  According to the Deering appraisal, the house and land were valued at $725,000 as of September 26, 2002.Â  Husband had the land and house appraised by Keith Ridgeway, who valued the property at $567,400. Â Although the final divorce decree had â€œ$567,400â€ typed as the value adopted by the court, the family court judge crossed through this amount, wrote â€œ$725,000â€ as the value, and initialed the change.Â  Thus, the final written order adopted Wifeâ€™s value for the acreage and home.Â  
Because the family court was free to accept Wifeâ€™s valuation over Husbandâ€™s, we find no abuse of discretion in the valuation of the marital home.Â  

B.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees

Noting that Wife did not receive a divorce based on adultery, alimony, or transmutation of property, Husband argues Wifeâ€™s attorney did not obtain a beneficial result and, thus, the family court erred in awarding her $15,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
The family court may order payment of attorneyâ€™s fees to a party pursuant to statute.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(H) (Supp. 2004).Â  Whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court, and the award will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 633-34, 576 S.E.2d 156, 167 (2003).Â  In determining whether an award of attorneyâ€™s fees should be granted, the family court should consider:Â  the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fee; the beneficial results obtained by counsel; the financial conditions of the parties; and the effect of the fee on each partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  To determine the amount of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider:Â  the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; counselâ€™s professional standing; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
In awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife, the family court noted it had considered all of the factors in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees and the appropriate amount of fees.Â  The family court noted that the case involved many issues, including novel issues of law, and that Wifeâ€™s attorney devoted a great deal of time to the case.Â  The court specifically stated that although â€œthe court was not persuaded as to all the relief sought by [Wifeâ€™s] attorney, beneficial results were clearly obtained.â€ 
We agree with the family court.Â  Although Wife was unsuccessful in her attempt to use Connecticut law to obtain property purchased prior to 1996 and to receive a finding that property had been transmuted, she was successful in obtaining a finding that the parties were common law married, she received half of the post-1996 marital estate, and she was allowed to resume her pre-marital name.Â  The family court adequately considered the factors, and we find no abuse of discretion.Â  
II. Wifeâ€™s Appeal

A.   Â Alimony

Wife argues the family court erred in denying her alimony because the court failed to give adequate weight to the statutory factors by placing too much emphasis on the length of the marriage.[1]Â  We agree.
â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 292, 617 S.E.2d 359, 362 (2005).Â  The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse in the position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  
Factors to be considered in making an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and non-marital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œOur inquiry on appeal is not whether the family court gave the same weight to particular factors as this court would have; rather, our inquiry extends only to whether the family court abused its considerable discretion in assigning weight to the applicable factors.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 186, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œNo one factor is dispositive.â€Â  Id. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 425; Nienow v. Nienow, 268 S.C. 161, 171, 232 S.E.2d 504, 510 (1977) (holding that in alimony considerations, â€œall of the facts and circumstances disclosed by the record should be considered; no one factor should be determined dispositiveâ€). 
At the time of trial, Wife was sixty-seven years old and Husband was seventy-five years old.Â  The parties lived together from 1971 until 2002.Â  Their common law marriage came into existence when the couple moved to South Carolina in 1996, and the marriage lasted until the parties divorced nearly eight years later in 2004.Â  Nothing in the record indicated that either party suffered from ill health other than â€œinfirmities of age.â€Â  Husband was a retired veterinarian while Wife only had a high school education.Â  Wife received $415 a month in social security income.Â  Husband admitted he had â€œvastly moreâ€ income and resources than Wife, grossing more than $99,000 in 2002 from social security, retirement accounts, investment income, and $8,000 per month from the Connecticut rental property. 
The parties maintained a high standard of living, living in a large house with no debt.Â  Wife was awarded fifty percent of the marital property, minus amounts she withdrew during the litigation, for a total award of $464,850.Â  In addition to his award of fifty percent of the marital estate, Husband had access to substantial property, including:Â  a gun collection valued at $200,000; rental property in Connecticut; and separate Fidelity accounts valued at $159,000.Â  There was a specific finding by the family court in apportioning the marital property that there was â€œmarital misconduct on the part of [Husband] which the court believes contributed significantly to the breakup of the marriage.â€Â  
Although the family court indicated that it considered the appropriate factors in denying Wife alimony, the family court focused primarily on the length of the partiesâ€™ marriage, stating as follows:

The court denies [Wifeâ€™s] application for alimony and finds that the duration of the marriage, from 1996 forward, with the final separation of the parties occurring in 2002, to be the conclusive factor.Â  While the court recognizes that the other factors including financial conditions of the parties, needs of the party seeking alimony, respective earning capacities and individual wealth, conduct of the [Husband], ability to pay alimony, and actual income of the parties would militate in favor of [Wife], the court feels these do not outweigh the factor of the duration of the marriage.

The court denied Wifeâ€™s argument on reconsideration that the court should have awarded alimony considering the statutory factors and â€œabundant caselaw.â€Â  
We agree with Wife that the family court abused its discretion in denying alimony.Â  Despite language in the order stating the family court had considered all the statutory factors and they militated in favor of Wife receiving alimony, the entire decision hinged on the length of the marriage.[2]Â  Our courts have not determined that a relatively short marriage is the single determinative factor in denying alimony; alimony has been found proper in some cases where the marriage was of a much shorter duration than that in the present case.Â  See Nienow, 268 S.C. at 172, 232 S.E.2d at 510 (remanding the issue of alimony for the family court to consider permanent periodic alimony to the wife in a fourteen-month marriage in light of â€œwifeâ€™s accustomed standard of living, the disparity between the partiesâ€™ wealth, and their respective earning capacitiesâ€); McDowell v. McDowell, 300 S.C. 96, 100, 386 S.E.2d 468, 470 (Ct. App. 1989) (affirming an award of alimony to the wife in a marriage of less than three years duration, despite the â€œrelatively shortâ€ length of the marriage, after considering the other factors relevant to an alimony award); Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 301-03, 372 S.E.2d 107, 114-15 (Ct. App. 1988) (finding the family court erred in not awarding permanent periodic alimony in a fourteen-month marriage where the factors favored alimony).Â  Further, Husbandâ€™s fault led to the breakup of the marriage, and he should not be rewarded in the consideration of alimony based upon the marriageâ€™s length.Â  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 302-03, 372 S.E.2d at 115 (â€œAn at fault spouse cannot destroy a marriage and then claim its short duration entitles him to more favorable consideration when economic adjustments attendant to divorce are made.â€).Â  
Considering all the factors militating in favor of an award of alimony to Wife, especially the partiesâ€™ standard of living, their relative incomes, and Husbandâ€™s fault in the breakup of the marriage, the family court abused its discretion in only considering the length of the marriage.Â  Wife is entitled to alimony.Â  We remand this matter to the family court for a determination of the proper amount of alimony. 

 B. Nonmarital property

Wife argues the family court erred in failing to find that property obtained in Husbandâ€™s name prior to the move to South Carolina was transmuted into marital property. [3] Â  We disagree.
Property acquired prior to the marriage is generally considered nonmarital.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(2) (Supp. 2004).Â  Nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property.Â  In determining whether property has been transmuted, courts must consider whether the property:Â  (1) â€œbecomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable;â€ (2) is titled jointly; or (3) â€œis utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 98, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œTransmutation is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.â€Â  Id.Â  The burden is on the spouse claiming transmutation to produce objective evidence that the parties considered the property to be marital during the marriage.Â  Id.
In 1958, Husband purchased the property that housed his veterinary clinic, then became the shooting range, and later was leased in 1998 to Widewater for hotel development.Â  Wife did not draw a salary after 1973, and her support was always from Husbandâ€™s income from the clinic and shooting range.Â  Wife testified at the final hearing that she did not have control over the money from the lease of the Connecticut property and that sometimes the money was placed in the partiesâ€™ joint account while it went â€œother placesâ€ at times.Â  Husband testified at the hearing that he used money from the rental property to purchase equipment for the farm.Â Â Â Â  
The family court determined that any transmutation must have occurred, if at all, after the 1996 date of the common law marriage.Â  Reviewing the evidence, the court determined that Wife failed to meet her burden of proving transmutation of the Fidelity Investment account and the profits of the Connecticut property.Â  
We agree with the family court.Â  Although money from Husbandâ€™s separate property was used to purchase items for the farm or to benefit the parties, nothing in the record shows Husbandâ€™s intent to transmute the property or that the proceeds from the lease became commingled with marital property.Â  Further, mere use of the income from Husbandâ€™s separate property in support of the marriage does not transmute them into marital property.Â  Peterkin v. Peterkin, 293 S.C. 311, 313, 360 S.E.2d 311, 313 (1987) (noting that Husbandâ€™s separate property inherited or given to him was not transmuted into marital property merely by the use of income derived from this property in furtherance of the marriage).Â  Accordingly, Wife failed to prove transmutation of Husbandâ€™s separate property acquired prior the 1996 marriage.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
The family court did not err in determining the value of the marital home, awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees, and in determining certain property acquired in Husbandâ€™s name prior to the 1996 common law marriage was nonmarital and not transmuted.Â  However, we find the court abused its discretion in considering only the length of the marriage to the exclusion of all of the other statutory factors in denying Wife alimony.Â  We find Wife was entitled to alimony and remand the matter to the family court for a determination of the appropriate amount.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
REMANDED.
 HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.Â  

[1]Â  Wife also argues the court erred by failing to require security for the payment of support.Â  It does not appear that this issue has been raised below.Â  Thus, it is not preserved for appeal.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge are not preserved for appellate review). Â Â 
[2]Â  It appears the family court found the length of the common law marriage was to be measured only by the six years the parties lived together in South Carolina.Â  However, the marriage lasted nearly eight years until the partiesâ€™ divorce was final in 2004.Â  
[3]Â  Wife further argued in her brief that the property obtained while the parties lived in Connecticut should be considered marital property by this court because the parties considered themselves married while they lived there.Â  Wifeâ€™s counsel abandoned this argument at oral argument.Â  We therefore decline to address it.Â

title: Martin v. Rapid Plumbing
description: In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, Appellants posit a plethora of issues: (1)	The Circuit Court, in affirming the Appellate Panel, erred as a matter of law in failing to admit additional and newly discovered evidence; (2)	There is no evidence from which reasonable minds could conclude that the Claimant was not at maximum medical improvement and released to return to full duty work at the time of the hearing; (3)	The Employer properly terminated temporary total disability benefits; (4)	The Circuit Court erred in determining the time period for which penalties should be assessed should be extended beyond the date of the original hearing of the Single Commissioner; and (5)	The Circuit Court erred in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s order that Donald Johnson, M.D. of Charleston be the authorized treating physician.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ronald Edward Martin, Employee, Respondent,
v.
Rapid Plumbing, Employer, and Builders Mutual Ins. Co., Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4114
Heard May 8, 2006 â€“ Filed May 22, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard C. Detwiler and Mikell H. Wyman, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
Stephen B. Samuels, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Â In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Rapid Plumbing contends the circuit court erred in (1) affirming the appellate panelâ€™s order denying the motion to admit evidence; (2) determining that Ronald Edward Martin was not at maximum medical improvement (MMI); (3) finding Rapid Plumbing improperly terminated temporary total disability benefits; (4) affirming and extending the assessment of penalties; and (5) affirming the commissionâ€™s determination of the authorized treating physician.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Martin was a plumberâ€™s helper who had been employed by Rapid Plumbing for two months when he sustained a back injury while moving a fiberglass bathtub on May 28, 2002.Â  Martin filed for workersâ€™ compensation benefits and Rapid Plumbing began providing medical treatment.Â  Because Martin was unable to work, he was paid temporary total disability compensation starting on June 2, 2002.Â  
Martin visited Doctorâ€™s Care on June 2, 2002. Â An MRI showed bulging discs and an annular tear.Â  He received physical therapy, but after three sessions of physical therapy, he had not improved.Â  Martin returned to Doctorâ€™s Care on July 24, 2002. Â The doctor determined physical therapy should be discontinued and referred Martin to an orthopedic surgeon.Â  On August 7, 2002, Dr. William Felmly, an orthopedic surgeon, saw Martin.Â  Martin complained of numbness, weakness, and leg swelling.Â  Dr. Felmly noted, â€œThe left lower extremity shows a bit of weakness in plantar flexion, a little bit of weakness of EHL, half grade on the peroneal . . . .Â  The patient appears to have increased pain and discomfort on pinch test and rotation.â€Â  Notwithstanding these findings, Dr. Felmly discharged Martin and returned him to full duty work.Â  The return to work statement was faxed to Rapid Plumbing at Martinâ€™s request on August 10, 2002, and Martin returned to work on August 12, 2002.Â Â Â  
On the day he returned to work, Martin worked with two plumbers installing bathtubs.Â  He worked one full day cutting pipe, going up and down steps, lifting bathtubs, and unloading a truck.Â  By the end of the day, Martin was â€œcrawling around on [his] kneesâ€ and his â€œlegs and back were hurting real bad.â€Â  The next day, Martin advised Rapid Plumbing of his condition and was told to return to Doctorâ€™s Care.Â  When Martin returned to Doctorâ€™s Care, they would not see him and the carrier refused to authorize the visit.Â  At his own expense, Martin saw Dr. Donald Johnson at Carolina Spine Institute on September 11, 2002.Â  Dr. Johnson noted an â€œeasy to seeâ€ annular tear on Martinâ€™s MRI and found his symptoms to be consistent with that injury.Â  Dr. Johnson recommended further treatment, and Martin was taken out of work.
Rapid Plumbing terminated Martinâ€™s temporary compensation on August 10, 2002.Â  Rapid Plumbing served a Form 15 on Martinâ€™s attorney sometime between August 28, 2002 and September 9, 2002.Â  The Form 15 alleged compensation had been stopped on August 10, 2002 because â€œclaimant has been released to return to work without restrictions and employment has been offered.â€Â  No supporting documentation was attached.Â  Martinâ€™s attorney signed the Form 15 and requested a hearing to determine whether Rapid Plumbing legally terminated temporary compensation.Â  
A single commissioner heard the case on December 19, 2002.Â  During cross-examination of Martin, defense counsel introduced a surveillance videotape taken around December 10, 2002.Â  The videotape showed Martin unloading wood from a pickup truck and using a log splitter to split the wood into firewood.Â  Notwithstanding the video, the single commissioner issued a decision on February 20, 2003 finding Rapid Plumbing had illegally terminated Martinâ€™s temporary compensation and Martin was not at MMI. Â Rapid Plumbing was ordered to reinstate compensation and pay a 25% penalty to Martin.Â  The commissioner designated Dr. Johnson as the authorized treating physician and ordered Rapid Plumbing to provide additional medical treatment as directed by Dr. Johnson.Â Â Â  
Rapid Plumbing appealed to the appellate panel of the workersâ€™ compensation commission.Â  The appellate panel heard the matter, and on October 29, 2003 one of the commissionerâ€™s wrote the parties advising them of the panelâ€™s decision.Â  The commission noted it was affirming, but authorized Rapid Plumbingâ€™s counsel â€œto send Dr. Johnson a letter, with the videotape enclosed, simply stating whether or not, based on his viewing of the videotape, he still believes that the Claimant is not at MMI.â€Â  The letter stated that in the event Dr. Johnson changed his opinion regarding MMI and medical treatment, â€œit would be appropriate for the Defendants to then file a Form 21, Stop Pay.â€Â  
On February 23, 2004, Dr. Johnson wrote a letter stating, â€œAfter reviewing Mr. Martinâ€™s videotape, I do believe that he is at maximum medical improvement.â€Â  Dr. Johnson opined, â€œI would assign him an eight percent (8%) impairment to the whole person.Â  I would place no particular restrictions on him at this time.â€Â  Rapid Plumbing sought to reopen the record and obtain a reversal based on the Johnson letter.Â  The panel heard arguments and concluded Rapid Plumbing had raised no new issues.Â  On June 10, 2004, the appellate panel issued an order affirming in part and reversing in part the single commissioner.Â  The appellate panel reduced the penalty period to August 10, 2002 through December 19, 2002.Â  Rapid Plumbing appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the appellate panel, but applied the penalty to the period from August 10, 2002 to July 9, 2004â€”the date when Rapid Plumbing resumed payment of temporary total disability.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the workersâ€™ compensation commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 467, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 457, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005); Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 2005); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527,Â  593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (2005).
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â Â  Anderson v.
Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 492, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 48, 515 S.E.2d 532, 533 (1999); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â 
Accordingly, a reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions
of fact. Stephen, 324 S.C. at 337, 478 S.E.2d at 76.Â  Instead, review of issues of fact is limited to determining whether the findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record. Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 289, 599 S.E.2d at 610-11.Â  â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports the findings.â€Â  Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€Â  Howell v. Pacific Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Failure to Admit Evidence
Rapid Plumbing contends the appellate panel erred in failing to admit what it alleges was newly-discovered evidence, specifically the letter of Dr. Johnson dated February 23, 2004.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rapid Plumbing asseverates the Johnson letter should come in pursuant to 25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-707 (1997) which allows for the admission of newly-discovered evidence.Â  The evidence sought to be admitted does not meet the standard for newly-discovered evidence.Â Â  Regulation 67-707 (1997) provides that in order to introduce new evidence into the record on a case on review: 

  C.Â  The moving party must establish that the new evidence is of the same nature and character required for granting a new trial and show: (1) The evidence sought to be introduced is not evidence of a cumulative or impeaching character but would likely have produced a different result had the evidence been procurable at the first hearing; and (2) The evidence was not known to the moving party at the time of the first hearing, by reasonable diligence the new evidence could not have been secured, and the discovery of the new evidence is being brought to the attention of the Commission immediately upon its discovery.

25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-707 (1997)
The requirements that the evidence must not be known to the party and could not have been secured by reasonable diligence have not been satisfied.Â  The Johnson letter or its equivalent could have been secured at the first hearing by reasonable diligence.Â  Rapid Plumbing had possession of the tape, yet failed to have a doctor review it.Â  Additionally, Rapid Plumbing did not make a motion to adjourn or leave the record open to develop the evidence.Â Â Â  
A conflicting doctorâ€™s report created after a hearing does not mandate a new trial.Â  See Ancrum v. Low Country Steaks, 317 S.C. 188, 193, 452 S.E.2d 609, 612 (Ct. App. 1994) (noting that even if physicianâ€™s reports, indicating that workersâ€™ compensation claimant possibly suffered from a herniated disc, were of same nature and character as that required for granting new trial, claimant failed to establish that, by reasonable diligence, such evidence could not have previously been secured and, thus, claimant was not entitled to a new trial based on newly discovered evidence).Â  Rapid Plumbing could have obtained a letter or testimony from Dr. Johnson regarding MMI and provided the evidence at the initial hearing.Â  Because it failed to do so, Rapid Plumbing cannot now argue it deserves a new trial.Â  The appellate panel merely allowed Rapid Plumbing to develop the record for a future Form 21 hearing by permitting it to communicate directly with Dr. Johnson.Â Â  In no way did the appellate panel state it would allow Rapid Plumbing to admit a letter by Dr. Johnson.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in finding the Johnson letter should not be admitted.Â  
II. MMI
Rapid Plumbing argues the circuit court erred in finding Martin was not at MMI, when there was no evidence to support that conclusion.Â  We disagree.Â  
The appellate panelâ€™s factual findings are supported by substantial evidence.Â Â  â€œMaximum medical improvement is a term used to indicate that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment.â€Â  Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp, 319 S.C. 24, 28, 459 S.E.2d 324, 327 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Rapid Plumbing contends the circuit court erred in finding Martin was not at MMI because (1) Dr. Felmly returned Martin to work with no restrictions; (2) Martin returned to work on August 12, 2002; and (3) â€œthe record reflects that the Claimant never presented an out of work excuse from any doctor to the employer or any conflicting doctorâ€™s opinions.â€ Â Rapid Plumbing argues this Court should rely on Dr. Felmlyâ€™s reports and Dr. Johnsonâ€™s letter to reverse the appellate panel.Â  
This Courtâ€™s review is restricted to the evidence considered by the appellate panel in reaching its decision.Â  The Johnson letter was not part of the record before the appellate panel and cannot be used to support Rapid Plumbingâ€™s argument.Â  Although the appellate panel could have conceivably found otherwise based on Dr. Felmlyâ€™s report, it weighed the conflicting opinions of the doctors and gave greater weight to Dr. Johnsonâ€™s report.Â  Any disagreements in the evidence are to be resolved exclusively by the appellate panel.Â  See Tiller v. National Health Care Center of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999) (stating that where there is a conflict in the evidence, either by different witnesses or by the same witness, the appellateÂ  panelâ€™s findings of fact are conclusive).Â  Dr. Johnson noted an â€œeasy to seeâ€ annular tear on Martinâ€™s MRI and found his symptoms to be consistent with that injury.Â  Further treatment was recommended and Martin was taken out of work.Â  Dr. Johnsonâ€™s report, combined with Martinâ€™s testimony, is sufficient evidence to affirm the appellate panelâ€™s findings.Â Â  
III. Termination of Temporary Total Disability Benefits
Rapid Plumbing contends the circuit court erred in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Rapid Plumbing was barred from stopping payment of temporary total disability benefits on the grounds of a perceived deficiency in the Form 15.Â Â  We disagree.Â  
The reason given on the Form 15 for the termination was because â€œClaimant has returned to work without restrictions and employment has been offered.â€Â  However, the statute is explicit that even under a Form 15, an employer can only terminate or suspend temporary compensation if one of the specified conditions is met.Â  The applicable condition in this case allows termination or suspension if â€œthe employee has returned to work; however, if the employee does not remain at work for a minimum of fifteen days, temporary disability payments must be resumed immediately[.]â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-260(B)(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  Because Martin did not remain at work for fifteen days, Rapid Plumbing was required to resume payments immediately after he left work on August 13, 2002.Â  
The rationale given by Rapid Plumbing is only applicable when suitable employment is offered but not accepted.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-190 (1985) (â€œIf an injured employee refuses employment procured for him suitable to his capacity and approved by the Commission he shall not be entitled to any compensation at any time during the continuance of such refusal.â€).Â  Thus, had Martin refused to return to work, Rapid Plumbing would have had legal justification to terminate his temporary compensation.Â  Because Martin willingly returned to work, but was unable to continue work after one day, the reason given by Rapid Plumbing did not apply.Â  
Even if Rapid Plumbing could have stopped temporary total disability benefits, it failed to follow the proper procedure for doing so as outlined by section 42-9-260 and regulation 67-504.Â  Rapid Plumbing terminated the compensation on August 10, 2002, but failed to file and serve the Form 15 until at least August 28, 2002, and failed to attach the supporting documentation as required by section 42-9-260.Â  These deficiencies are not mere technicalities, but are substantial deviations from the statutory procedure.Â Â  The circuit court was correct in finding Rapid Plumbing wrongfully terminated temporary benefits.Â  
IV. Penalty Period
The appellate panel affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s imposition of a 25% penalty on Rapid Plumbing on the overdue payments for temporary total disability benefits.Â  However, the single commissioner set the time for assessment of the penalty starting August 10, 2002 and continuing until Rapid Plumbing resumed paying the benefitsâ€”a time which had yet to occur.Â  The appellate panel reversed the commissioner in this aspect by limiting the penalty period to August 10, 2002 through December 19, 2002, the date of the hearing before the single commissioner.Â  The circuit court set the penalty period as August 10, 2002 through July 9, 2004â€”the date when Rapid Plumbing resumed payment of benefits.Â  Rapid Plumbing contends the court erred in increasing the penalty period.Â  We disagree. 
Section 42-9-260(G) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) requires employers to pay temporary total disability to an employee who has â€œbeen out of work due to a reported work related injuryâ€ for eight days.Â  The penalty language of section 42-9-260 provides:

(G)Â  Failure to comply with this section shall result in a twenty-five percent penalty imposed upon the carrier or employer computed on the amount of benefits withheld in violation of this section, and the amount of the penalty must be paid to the employee in addition to the amount of benefits withheld. Â However, the penalty does not apply if the employer or carrier has terminated or suspended benefits when the employee has returned to any employment at the same or similar wage.

Id. (emphasis added).
The language of section 42-9-260(G) is mandatory.Â  The statute sets the time of the penalty as beginning with the failure to comply with section 42-9-260 and continuing for as long as the benefits are wrongfully withheld.Â  The appellate panel did not have discretion to limit the duration of the penalty to a time other than the date when payment of benefits was resumed.Â  By the time the circuit court heard the case, the statutory penalty period had ended as Rapid Plumbing had resumed paying benefits to Martin.Â  Therefore, the circuit court correctly set the penalty period as beginning on August 10, 2002 and continuing through the date Rapid Pluming resumed payments to Martinâ€”i.e., July 9, 2004.Â  
Additionally, Rapid Plumbing complains of the compensation rate upon which the penalty was assessed.Â  However, Rapid Plumbing simply states the compensation rate should have been lower and fails to make an argument explaining its position.Â  â€œConclusory arguments constitute an abandonment of the issue on appeal.â€Â 
Civil Action No.: 2001-CP-32-0711 Carolina Water Serv., Inc. v. Lexington County Joint Mun. Water and Sewer Commâ€™n, 367 S.C. 141, 149, 625 S.E.2d 227, 231 (Ct. App. 2006); see also Houck v. State Farm Fire and Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 17 n.5, 620 S.E.2d 326, 332 n.5 (2005) (noting an issue is abandoned if the appellantâ€™s brief treats it in a conclusory manner).Â  The single commissioner made the finding that the rate should be $230.12, and absent an argument as to why that calculation is wrong, we cannot reverse.Â  
V. Authorized Treating Physician
Rapid Plumbing argues the circuit court erred in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s order that Dr. Johnson be the authorized treating physician.Â  We disagree.Â  
As a preliminary matter, this issue has not been preserved for our review.Â  Rapid Plumbing failed to object and have the issue ruled on by the circuit court and did not file a timely motion for reconsideration.Â  See Talley v. S.C. Higher Ed. Tuition Grants Committee, 289 S.C. 483, 487, 347 S.E.2d 99, 101 (1986) (stating an issue raised in trial court but not ruled on by the trial court is not preserved for appellate review).Â Â  
Even had this issue been preserved for our review, it fails on the merits.Â  Regulation 67-509 states that while a claimant is receiving temporary compensation benefits, â€œ[t]he employerâ€™s representative chooses an authorized health care provider and pays for authorized treatment.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-509(A) (1990). However, section 42-15-60 of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act
provides: 


  Medical . . . treatment . . . shall be provided by the employer. In case of a controversy arising between employer and employee, the Commission may order such further medical, surgical, hospital or other treatment as may in the discretion of the Commission be necessary. . . . [T]he employer may, at his own option, continue to furnish or cause to be furnished, free of charge to the employee, and the employee shall accept an attending physician, unless otherwise ordered by the Commission. . . .Â  The refusal of an employee to accept any medical, hospital, surgical or other treatment when provided by the employer or ordered by the Commission shall bar such employee from further compensation until such refusal ceases and no compensation shall at any time be paid for the period of suspension unless in the opinion of the Commission the circumstances justified the refusal, in which case the Commission may order a change in the medical or hospital service. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985); See also Grattis v. Murells Inlet VFW #10420, 353 S.C. 100, 113-14, 576 S.E.2d 191, 197-98 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating that where it deems it necessary, the appellateÂ  panel may override an employerâ€™s choice of medical provider and may excuse a workersâ€™ compensation claimantâ€™s justified refusal to seek treatment from employerâ€™s provider, in these circumstances, the appellateÂ  panel may order a change in the medical or hospital service provided by employer to the claimant).Â Â Â  
The appellate panel is afforded discretion to order medical treatment under section 42-15-60 when a controversy such as the one in the instant case arises.Â  The designation of Dr. Johnson was consistent with the factual finding that additional treatment would lessen Martinâ€™s disability.Â  The refusal by Doctorâ€™s Care to see Martin and Dr. Johnsonâ€™s subsequent diagnosis created the controversy contemplated by the statute.Â  This is not a case where an employee is refusing treatment offered by an employer.Â  Rather, this is a situation where the employee feels he still needs treatment and the employer fails to provide it.Â  The appellate panel acted within its discretion and the circuit court was correct in affirming the order confirming Dr. Johnson as the authorized treating physician.Â  
CONCLUSION
The order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, J., concur.
