title: Smith v. NCCI
description: In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, Appellants posit a plethora of issues: (1) Did the Appellate Panel erroneously find as a fact and conclude as a matter of law that Respondent was subjected to unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment in the absence of detailed findings in the order addressing the proximate cause issue and the unusual and extraordinary employment factors;  (2) Did the Appellate Panel err in finding as a fact and concluding as a matter of law that Respondent suffered a compensable back injury; (3) Did the Appellate Panel err in finding as a fact and concluding as a matter of law that Respondent suffered a mental or psychological injury as an alleged consequence of continuing and unrelenting occupational stress; (4) Did the Appellate Panel err in finding that the nature of the test audit program was inextricably intertwined with unusual and extraordinary stress; (5) Did the Appellate Panel err in awarding Respondent temporary total disability benefits and medical treatment from March 19, 1999, when the date of the alleged injury is May 27, 1999; (6) Did the Appellate Panel and the Circuit Court err as a matter of law in failing to address the proximate cause of the Respondentâ€™s purported mental injury or disability, when substantial evidence reveals that any purported mental injury results from non-occupational stressors; (7) Did the Appellate Panel and the Circuit Court err in finding and concluding the case is compensable in view of a lack of subject matter jurisdiction over this claim; and (8) Did the Appellate Panel and the Circuit Court err in finding that Respondent timely filed a Workersâ€™ Compensation claim and gave timely notice of such to Appellants.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Tom Smith, Claimant/Respondent,
v.
NCCI, Inc. as Employer, and Liberty Insurance Corporation, as Carrier,
Defendants/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4115
Heard May 8, 2006 â€“ Filed May 22, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Vernon F. Dunbar, of Greenville, for Appellants.
Preston F. McDaniel, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  NCCI appeals the trial courtâ€™s order affirming the decision of the appellate panel of the workersâ€™ compensation commission (appellate panel).Â  NCCI argues the trial court erred in finding (1) Tom Smithâ€™s mental injury was caused by unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment with NCCI; (2) Smithâ€™s physical injury to his back arose out of and in the course of employment with NCCI; (3) Smithâ€™s injuries were aggravated by his employment with NCCI; (4) Smith was entitled to disability benefits beginning March 19, 1999; (5) NCCI was not entitled to credit for short- and long-term disability benefits received by Smith; and (6) Smithâ€™s claim was not barred by the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In April 1991, Smith began working with NCCI as a supervisor for the Test Audit Department of NCCIâ€™s Atlantic Division.Â  Before working with NCCI, Smith worked as auditor with two other companies for a total of thirteen years.Â  Smith commuted from Tampa to Boca Raton during his time as a supervisor.Â  In 1993, Smith voluntarily stepped down from his supervisor position and became a senior auditor in Tampa.
As an auditor in Florida, Smith conducted test audits of insurance policies from both the voluntary market and the assigned risk market.Â  A test audit is a process in which an insurance companyâ€™s audits are checked to determine whether the premiums being charged are sufficient for the coverage being provided.Â  Smith primarily worked in the area around Tampa and generally worked between forty and fifty hours a week.Â  Smith usually met NCCIâ€™s weekly production requirements of nine audits.Â  During this time, NCCI recognized Smith as one of its best test auditors in Tampa.Â  In fact, Smith received a couple of awards in recognition of his production and work quality.
At some point, NCCI made various operational changes.Â  First, NCCI changed its fee structure.Â  NCCI changed from an assessment-based system, wherein NCCI would simply assess the insurance companies for all of the services the company requested and the various insurance commissions required, to a fee-for-services-based system, wherein NCCI charged an individual fee for the services performed.Â  In addition, NCCI had a change in management.Â  The new management heavily focused on production and meeting production goals.Â  As part of the change in management, NCCI placed a new vice-president, Steve Axleray, in charge of its auditing divisions.Â  In the summer of 1995, Axleray met with NCCIâ€™s auditors, chastised them for their lack of production, and informed them the new management expected increased production.Â  Axleray informed the auditors that a voluntary severance package could be taken by anyone that did not wish to continue working with the newly-structured NCCI.
In June 1995, shortly after NCCIâ€™s operational changes went into effect, NCCI asked Smith to move to South Carolina and continue working as a test auditor.Â  Smith had extensive knowledge of the South Carolina Test Audit Program because he authored the program.Â  Based on this knowledge and his understanding that the program focused on quality audits as opposed to production, Smith decided to stay with NCCI and turn down the severance package.Â  Smith replaced NCCIâ€™s sole auditor in South Carolina, Elizabeth Crosby, whom he had hired to start the program.
The South Carolina test audit program was unique.Â  The program focused specifically on the assigned risk market.Â  Test audits on the assigned risk market are generally more time consuming and difficult than audits on the voluntary market.Â  The assigned risk market, unlike the voluntary market, typically consists of smaller and newer companies that have disorganized or incomplete records.Â  In addition, companies in the assigned risk market are usually in hard-to-find locations.
When Smith arrived in South Carolina, his job as a test auditor was very different from both his Florida job and from what he had envisioned and designed.Â  First, Smithâ€™s work was dispersed across the entire state and consisted of very few local assignments.Â  As a result, Smith was consistently driving six hundred miles or greater every week even though the job description called for driving only two to three hundred miles per week.Â  Second, despite the programâ€™s design, Smith discovered NCCI management was more concerned with the quantity of the audits conducted than quality of the audits.Â  Throughout Smithâ€™s time in South Carolina, NCCI constantly pressured Smith about meeting production goals.Â  Third, although the job description provided for a forty-hour work week, Smith routinely worked over seventy hours per week and habitually worked on weekends.Â  Further, Smith regularly stayed in hotels two to four nights a week when the job description provided that overnight stays should average one to two nights per week.
In October 1995 Smith took medical leave from work.Â  Smith testified he took leave because the demands of the South Carolina job were â€œjust nothing close to what [Smith] was told it was going to be.â€Â  During this period, Smith was treated by Dr. Roger Deal.Â  Dealâ€™s records indicate Smith had been demonstrating symptoms of depression, bi-polar disorder, and obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) in the year preceding July 1995, and Smith was still dealing with OCD and depression at the time of their initial visit. Â Dealâ€™s notes indicate Smith was taking assorted prescription drugs when they first met.Â  Deal prescribed various medicines to assist Smith in his recovery.Â  In March 1996, Smith was able to return to work.
In February 1999, NCCI changed Smithâ€™s company car from a full-size Ford Taurus to a smaller, subcompact Saturn.Â  Smith began complaining of back pains immediately thereafter.Â  Within a couple of months NCCI provided Smith with a raise to allow him to purchase a new, bigger car.
Smith visited Dr. Eleanay Ogburu-Ognonnaya for treatment of his back pain in March 1999.Â  Ogburu-Ognonnayaâ€™s records from March 1999 indicate Smith specifically noted his new company car had no lumbar support, was very uncomfortable, and limited leg movement.Â  Smith averred Ogburu-Ognonnaya advised him to reduce his driving and that the kind of driving required for Smithâ€™s work would make Smithâ€™s back worse.
In May 1999, Smith took leave from work and filed for short-term disability benefits.Â  In his request for short-term disability, Smith stated his last day of work was May 26, 1999.Â  Smith noted the symptoms that led him to cease working were (1) excessive stress and fatigue, which he listed as an illness, and (2) an injury to his lower back.Â  Smith provided March 8, 1999 as the date of onset of the symptoms for excessive fatigue, and the week of February 15-19, 1999 as the first onset of symptoms for the back injury.
On June 1, 2000, Smith filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim alleging injuries to the â€œback, legs, psychological/whole personâ€ culminating on May 27, 1999.Â  Hearings were conducted in this matter on August 23, 2001; February 28, 2002; and March 11, 2002.Â  NCCI alleges Smith withdrew his original claim after NCCI filed a Form 51 and filed another claim raising the same allegations on November 11, 2000, which was again withdrawn without prejudice by consent on March 13, 2001.Â  NCCI asserts Smith refiled his claim on March 19, 2001, making identical assertions.Â  The record evidences neither Smithâ€™s withdrawal of the original claim nor the filing of subsequent claims.Â  Nevertheless, whether Smith filed in June 2000 or in March 2001 is irrelevant because the allegations and issues are the same.
The hearing commissioner found Smith suffered a compensable mental or psychological injury due to unusual and extraordinary conditions of his employment.Â  The commissioner further found Smith sustained a compensable back injury as a result of his work activity requiring Smith to drive extremely long distances in a subcompact vehicle.Â  The commissioner awarded Smith temporary total disability compensation benefits and medical benefits.Â  The commissioner denied NCCI credit for short- and long-term disability benefits paid to Smith.
NCCI appealed the commissionerâ€™s decision to the appellate panel.Â  The appellate panel determined that all of the commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law were correct and adopted the commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.Â  NCCI appealed to the circuit court, and the circuit court affirmed the appellate panel.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency.â€Â  Clark v. Aiken County Govâ€™t, 366 S.C. 102, 107, 620 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005) establishes the substantial evidence rule as the standard of review.Â  See also Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 133, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  Under this standard, a reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) and (e) (2005).
â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workers Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports its findings.â€Â 
Peoples v. Henry Co., 364 S.C. 123, 127, 611 S.E.2d 527, 528-29 (Ct. App. 2005); see also 
Frame v. Resort Servs. Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 528, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIt is not within our province to reverse
findings of the Commission which are supported by substantial evidence.â€).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€Â 
Baggott v. S. Music, Inc., 330 S.C. 1, 5, 496 S.E.2d 852, 854 (1998).Â  â€œQuantitatively, substantial evidence is something less than the weight of the evidence.â€Â 
Howell v. Pac. Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the commissionâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â 
Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 188, 564 S.E.2d 694, 697 (Ct. App. 2002).
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.  
         Are NCCIâ€™s issues on appeal properly preserved for our review?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did Smith suffer a compensable mental injury caused by unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment with NCCI?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III.  
         Did Smith suffer a compensable physical injury to his back caused by conditions of employment with NCCI?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        IV.   
         Did the appellate panel err in finding that Smithâ€™s injuries were aggravated by his employment conditions with NCCI?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        V. 
         Did the appellate panel err by awarding temporary total disability benefits commencing on March 19, 1999?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        VI.      
         Did the appellate panel erroneously deny NCCI credit for short- and long-term benefits received by Smith?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        VII.  
         Did the appellate panel err in finding Smithâ€™s claim is not barred by the statute of limitations?
      
      
        
        
      
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Preservation
Initially, Smith argues each of NCCIâ€™s issues are not preserved for review. Â When a trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument raised, and the appellant makes no Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to obtain a ruling, the appellate court may not address the issue.Â  Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).
The circuit court considered all of the issues raised and affirmed the appellate panelâ€™s order.Â  NCCIâ€™s Notice of Intent to Appeal to Circuit Court specifically raises each of the issues presented for appeal to this Court.Â  Accordingly, we find each of the issues presented for appeal was properly preserved for our review.
II. Mental Injury
NCCI contends the appellate panel erred in finding Smith suffered a compensable mental injury under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because Smithâ€™s employment conditions were not extraordinary and unusual and did not cause Smithâ€™s mental injury.Â  We disagree.
A compensable injury under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is defined by section 42-1-160, which states:

â€œInjuryâ€ and â€œpersonal injuryâ€ shall mean only injury by accident arising out of and in the course of the employment . . .

  Stress arising out of and in the course of employment unaccompanied by physical injury and resulting in mental illness or injury is not a personal injury
unless it is established that the stressful employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual in comparison to the normal conditions of the employment.

  Stress arising out of and in the course of employment unaccompanied by physical injury is not considered compensable if it results from any event or series of events which is incidental to normal employer/employee relations including, but not limited to, personnel actions by the employer such as disciplinary actions, work evaluations, transfers, promotions, demotions, salary reviews, or terminations, except when these actions are taken in an extraordinary and unusual manner.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).
In order to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits for a mental injury, the claimant must prove both: (1) that he was exposed to unusual and extraordinary conditions in his employment; and (2) that these unusual and extraordinary conditions were the proximate cause of his mental breakdown.Â 
Doe v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Disabilities and Special Needs, 364 S.C. 411, 418, 613 S.E.2d 785, 789 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The requirement of â€œunusual or extraordinary conditions in employmentâ€ refers to conditions to the particular job in which the injury occurs, not to conditions of employment in general. Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 457, 535 S.E.2d 438, 443 (2000).
As the finder of fact, the appellate panel found the conditions of Smithâ€™s employment were extraordinary and unusual for a test auditor.Â  The panel specifically found the unique requirements of conducting the South Carolina test audit program made the application of the general standards for a test auditor â€œunattainable, unreasonable, and unusual.â€Â  The appellate panel further found NCCIâ€™s unreasonable expectations and production goals, the continual and unrelenting criticism and pressure to meet these unattainable production goals, and Smithâ€™s extremely long work hours all contributed to cause Smithâ€™s mental injury.
A. Extraordinary and Unusual Conditions
There is substantial evidence in the record to support the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Smith, as a test auditor in South Carolina, was exposed to unusual and extraordinary conditions in his employment.
First, experts in the auditing industry opined that Smithâ€™s employment conditions were extraordinary and unusual.
Second, Smith worked in the South Carolina test audit program, a unique program that focused specifically on the assigned risk market.Â  As a result, meeting production goals in South Carolina was more difficult than meeting production goals in other states that tested both the assigned risk market and the voluntary market.
Third, Smith was unlike other auditors with NCCI in that he mainly conducted test audits.Â  NCCI guidelines allowed test auditors to conduct some variation of inspections to help satisfy the production requirement of nine test audits per week.Â  Bowles, a test auditor with NCCI in South Carolina from 1995 through 1999, testified his job involved conducting test audits and less time consuming inspections while Smith focused â€œjust about 100% on the test audits.â€
Fourth, Smithâ€™s employment conditions in South Carolina were unusual because his assignments were dispersed throughout South Carolina and required significant amounts of driving.Â  Smith testified he typically drove in excess of six hundred miles per week despite the job description calling for only two to three hundred miles per week.Â  Other NCCI test auditors averaged well below six hundred miles of driving per week.
Finally, NCCI constantly and continuously harassed Smith about production. Â Smith testified he received a â€œsteady flowâ€ of memos, â€œat times every day,â€ informing him NCCI needed more production.Â  While the record indicates NCCI pressured all of its auditors, the pressure on Smith was exacerbated because the constant demands were being made despite Smithâ€™s unique situation.Â  In addition, the testimony provides that other companies did not pressure auditors to the extent NCCI did.Â  The pressure imposed on Smith was not â€œincidental to normal employer/employee relationsâ€ because of the constant and continuous nature of the demands and because of Smithâ€™s unique position.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).
Substantial evidence in the record supports a finding that Smithâ€™s employment conditions were extraordinary and unusual.
B. Cause of Mental Injury
There is substantial evidence in the record supporting the appellate panelâ€™s finding that the extraordinary and unusual conditions of Smithâ€™s employment caused his mental injury.
First, doctorsâ€™ opinions and records indicate Smithâ€™s condition was linked to stress from his job.Â  Dr. Franklin J. Klohn, Jr., in an answer to an interrogatory, opined that Smithâ€™s psychological condition was most probably caused by the stressors of his job.Â  In late February 1999, Smith visited Dr. Rex Rawls and complained of â€œChronic fatigue syndrome, worsening over the last eight years.â€Â  Rawls provided Smith with a note stating that he may need a week off to try to recover from the excessive fatigue.Â  Rawlsâ€™ notes from a visit in May 1999 provide that Smith was requesting disability â€œso he wonâ€™t have to continue with his high stress job.â€
Second, Smithâ€™s testimony and actions lend further support to the finding that Smithâ€™s employment conditions caused his mental injury.Â  Smith testified that he took medical leave from work from October 1995 through March 1996 because the demands of the South Carolina job were â€œjust nothing close to what [Smith] was told it was going to be.â€Â  Further, when Smith filed for short-term disability in May 1999 he cited excessive stress and fatigue as one of the reasons for the request and listed March 8, 1999 as the date of the onset of the symptoms.
Third, another auditor, Chris Bowles, testified he developed health problems as a result of the stresses accompanied by working with NCCI.Â  Specifically, Bowles testified he was diagnosed with Barrettâ€™s esophagus (a pre-cancerous condition) and ulcers of the esophagus, which he attributed to the employment conditions with NCCI.
The record provides substantial evidence to support a finding that NCCIâ€™s employment conditions caused Smithâ€™s injury.
Admittedly, the record indicates Smith had numerous non-employment stressors that may have contributed to or caused his mental injury.Â  The record provides that during the course of Smithâ€™s employment (1) he had trouble selling his home; (2) he was diagnosed with bi-polar disorder and depression prior to moving to South Carolina; (3) he was involved in a lawsuit regarding the construction of his South Carolina home; (4) he received a couple of speeding tickets; (5) his daughter had numerous medical problems; (6) he was involved in a lawsuit stemming from a 1995 motor vehicle accident; and (7) he had various medical problems including an esophagus problem and two angioplasty surgeries or treatments.Â  However, â€œ[t]he findings of the agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.â€ Â Kearse v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d 892, 893 (1995).Â  Moreover, the possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 338-39, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999).Â  Thus, because there is substantial evidence in the record to support the finding of the appellate panel, the contrary evidence is inconsequential.
C. Proximate Cause
NCCI next asserts the appellate panelâ€™s order failed to address the issue of proximate cause of Smithâ€™s mental injury, and therefore, this Court should remand the case and allow the appellate panel the opportunity to make a finding of cause.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code Annotated section 1-23-350 (2005) provides, in relevant part, that â€œ[i]f . . . a party submitted proposed findings of fact, [an agency] decision shall include a ruling upon each proposed finding.â€Â  The findings of fact made by the appellate panel must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing court to determine whether the evidence supports the findings.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs. Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 531, 593 S.E.2d 491, 497 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  When an administrative agency acts without first making the proper factual findings required by law, the proper procedure is to remand the case and allow the agency the opportunity to make those findings. Fox v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 282, 461 S.E.2d 392, 395 (1995).
The appellate panel made sufficient findings of fact regarding the proximate cause of Smithâ€™s mental injury.Â  The appellate panel adopted the commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.Â  The commissionerâ€™s order specifically states:

[Smithâ€™s] psychological condition was as a result of unusual and/or extraordinary conditions in [Smithâ€™s] employment specifically unreasonable expectations and production goals from his employer, continual and unrelenting stress on [Smith] including criticism and pressure to meet those unattainable goals and extremely long hours in excess of 70 hours per week put in by [Smith] in an effort to try to reach those goals.

Therefore, the appellate panelâ€™s findings of fact are sufficiently detailed regarding the proximate cause of Smithâ€™s mental injury.
III. Physical Injury
NCCI alleges the appellate panel erred in finding Smith suffered a compensable injury to his back.Â  Specifically, NCCI argues the appellate panel committed error in disregarding the report of ergonomist Elizabeth Neal Miall and in finding Smithâ€™s excessive driving led to his injury because he had been driving long distances for years.Â  We disagree.
For an injury to be compensable, it must arise out of and in the course of employment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œThe phrase â€˜arising out ofâ€™ refers to the origin of the cause of the accident.â€Â 
Clade v. Champion Labs., 330 S.C. 8, 10, 496 S.E.2d 856, 857 (1998).Â  â€œâ€˜An injury arises out of employment when there is apparent to the rational mind, upon consideration of all the circumstances, a causal relationship between the conditions under which the work is to be performed and the resulting injury.â€™â€Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 518, 466 S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996) (quoting Owings v. Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 315 S.C. 297, 299, 433 S.E.2d 869, 871 (1993)).
â€œThe claimant has the burden of proving facts that will bring the injury within the workersâ€™ compensation law, and such award must not be based on surmise, conjecture or speculation.â€
Clade, 330 S.C. at 11, 496 S.E.2d at 857.Â  However, injured employees are not required to prove their injuries were caused by specific events in order to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Id. at 12, 496 S.E.2d at 858.
The appellate panel found Smithâ€™s back injury arose out of and in the course of his employment with NCCI.Â  There is substantial evidence in the record to support this finding.Â  First, Smith complained of neck and lower back pain immediately after receiving the smaller company car.Â  Smith testified that his back began hurting him the very first day he drove the subcompact Saturn.Â  Smith further professed his doctor instructed him to take time off from work because the extensive driving required by Smithâ€™s job made his back injury worse.Â  In addition, the record provides that in June 1999, Dr. Donald Johnson, with the Carolina Spine Institute, opined Smith â€œneeds to be out of the work placeâ€ because driving exacerbates Smithâ€™s lower back pain.Â  Further, Dr. Ogburu-Ognonnayaâ€™s records indicate that in March 1999, Smith specifically noted his new company car had no lumbar support, was very uncomfortable, and limited his leg movement.Â  Finally, a memo from Bailey to NCCI indicates Bailey experienced similar discomforts with the smaller company car.
The record contains evidence suggesting Smithâ€™s back injury may not have been caused by his employment conditions.Â  In 1995 Smithâ€™s back and neck were injured in a car accident, and, over the years, Smith sometimes informed various doctors of minor back pains and persistent headaches.Â  NCCI presented an ergonomic analysis from Miall stating there were no appreciable differences between the ride, suspension, and measurements of the two cars, and â€œyou could determine [Smithâ€™s] back pain was not caused by the use of the Saturn SL 2.â€Â  However, when a conflict in the evidence exists, the findings of fact of the administrative agency are conclusive.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 338-39, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999).Â  The final
determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the appellate panel. Â Cf. 
Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).
Because there is substantial evidence in the record to support the appellate panelâ€™s findings, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision.
IV. Aggravation of Injuries
NCCI next argues the appellate panel did not make sufficient findings of fact to support its ruling that Smithâ€™s employment conditions aggravated Smithâ€™s mental and physical injuries.Â  We agree.
â€œThe right of a claimant to compensation for aggravation of a pre-existing condition arises only where there is a dormant condition which has produced no disability but which becomes disabling by reason of the aggravating injury.â€Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 SC 487, 493, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001).Â  â€œAggravation of pre-existing psychiatric problems is compensable if that aggravation is caused by a work-related physical injury.â€Â  Id.
The appellate panelâ€™s ruling on this issue is insufficient.Â  The findings of fact made by the appellate panel must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing court to determine whether the evidence supports the findings. Â Cf. Frame v. Resort Servs. Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 531, 593 S.E.2d 491, 497 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  When an administrative agency acts without first making the proper factual findings required by law, the proper procedure is to remand the case and allow the agency the opportunity to make those findings.Â  Fox v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 282, 461 S.E.2d 392, 395 (1995).Â  The appellant panelâ€™s order makes no specific finding that Smithâ€™s injuries were aggravated by his employment conditions; the only reference to the aggravation of a pre-existing condition is that one of the cases that specifically controls this case is Anderson, 343 SC 487, 541 S.E.2d 526.Â  The appellate panelâ€™s order is not sufficiently detailed to enable a review by this Court; nevertheless, because we affirm on other grounds we do not need to remand for a proper finding of fact on this issue.
V. Payment of Benefits
NCCI asserts the appellate panel erred in awarding disability benefits and medical treatment beginning on March 19, 1999, prior to the date of the alleged accident and disability.Â  We disagree.
Sections 42-9-200 and -230 of the South Carolina Code Annotated (1985 and Supp. 2005) provide that compensation for disability shall be allowed from the date of disability.Â  Section 42-15-60 states that medical benefits shall be provided â€œfor a period not exceeding ten weeks from the date of injury . . . and for such additional time as in the judgment of the Commission will tend to lessen the period of disability[.]â€Â  Essentially, workersâ€™ compensation benefits accrue along a time continuum: temporary total disability benefits are available from the date
of injury through the date of maximum medical improvement (MMI) and post-MMI benefits may be awarded either as a permanent total or partial disability, or as a percentage of impairment to a scheduled member.Â 
Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 414 n.2, 517 S.E.2d 698, 703 n.2 (Ct. App. 1999).
The record indicates Smithâ€™s injury began prior to the date the commission awarded medical benefits.Â  When Smith filed for short-term disability, he listed March 8, 1999 as the date of onset of the symptoms for excessive fatigue and the week of February 15-19, 1999 as the first onset of symptoms for the back injury.Â  Thus, the circuit court did not err in affirming the award of medical benefits commencing March 19, 1999.
VI. Credit
NCCI next contends the appellate panel erred in finding NCCI is not entitled to a credit for payment of short- and long-term disability benefits received by Smith.Â  Specifically, NCCI asserts it is entitled to a credit for benefits paid because Smith received short-term disability benefits from October 1995 through March 1996 and was awarded long-term disability benefits prior to May 27, 1999, the date Smithâ€™s injury admittedly culminated.Â  We disagree.
Initially we note this issue may not be preserved for our review.Â  Only issues raised and ruled upon by the commission are cognizable on appeal. See e.g., TNS Mills, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Rev., 331 S.C. 611, 503 S.E.2d 471 (1998).Â  The appellate panelâ€™s order does not specifically address this issue.
Although we find preservation tenuous at best, we nevertheless proceed to the merits.Â  Section 42-9-210 provides:

Any payments made by an employer to an injured employee during the period of his disability, or to his dependents, which by the terms of this Title were not due and payable when made may, subject to the approval of the Commission, be deducted from the amount to be paid as compensation; provided, that in the case of disability such deductions shall be made by shortening the period during which compensation must be paid and not by reducing the amount of the weekly payment.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-210 (1985).Â  â€œIn order for payments to be deductible, they must have been made with reference to liability under the provisions of the Act and intended to be in lieu of compensation.â€Â 
Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 298, 519 S.E.2d 583, 599 (Ct. App. 1999).
The record is devoid of evidence suggesting any short-term or long-term disability benefits received by Smith were made with reference to liability under the Act and in lieu of compensation.Â  Accordingly, we find the appellate panel did not err in finding that NCCI is not entitled to a credit for any short-term or long-term benefits paid to Smith.
VII. Statute of Limitations
Finally, NCCI alleges Smithâ€™s claim is barred by the statute of limitations prescribed in section 42-15-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  We find this argument manifestly without merit.
Section 42-15-40 provides â€œ[t]he right to compensation . . . is barred unless a claim is filed with the commission within two years after an accident[.]â€Â  Smithâ€™s mental and physical injury culminated in disability on May 27, 1999.Â  Smith filed his original Form 50 to initiate this claim on June 1, 2000.Â  Accordingly, we find Smithâ€™s claim is not barred by the statute of limitations.Â  Even if Smith filed on March 19, 2001, as asserted by NCCI, his claim still falls inside the two-year statute of limitations.
CONCLUSION
We conclude substantial evidence in the record supports the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Smith suffered a mental injury caused by unusual and extraordinary employment conditions with NCCI, and that Smith suffered a physical injury to his back arising out of and in the course of his employment with NCCI.Â  The appellate panel did not err in awarding benefits commencing March 19, 1999, and in denying NCCI a credit for benefits received by Smith.Â  We hold Smithâ€™s claim is not barred by the statute of limitations.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C. J., and GOOLSBY, J. concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Willie Cochran and Reggie James, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4116
Heard May 8, 2006 â€“ Filed May 30, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Tara Dawn Shurling, of Columbia, for Appellants.

 KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Willie Cochran and Reggie James were convicted by a jury of first-degree burglary and sentenced.Â  Reggie James was also convicted and sentenced for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.[1]Â  They appeal from the trial courtâ€™s granting of the Stateâ€™s Batson motion and quashing the first jury selected.Â  Batson v. I.

Early on, the trial court abandoned the Purkett-Adams procedure for a Batson motion.Â  The trial court failed to require the State to carry its burden of establishing purposeful racial discrimination in the third step of the Batson procedure.Â  The State urges us to excuse noncompliance with the third step of the Batson procedure because of Appellantsâ€™ â€œpatternâ€ of striking white jurors.Â  As noted, we find no such pattern, and the trial court made no such finding.Â  
Appellants exercised only half of their allotted strikes.Â  Appellantsâ€™ first and sixth strikes were exercised against black women.Â  In any event, the mere presence of a pattern would not justify a departure from the Purkett-Adams procedure.Â  See State v. The second jury was comprised of two black men, two white men, three black women, and five white women.Â  Appellants did not use any of their peremptory challenges, and the court forbade Appellants from striking those jurors it determined were improperly struck during the first jury selection.Â  Conversely, the State used four peremptory challenges, all on black jurors.Â  Appellants opposed the Stateâ€™s strikes and requested a Batson hearing.Â  At the second Batson hearing, the trial court scrupulously adhered to the mandated Batson process and required Appellants to show purposeful racial discrimination after the State offered race-neutral explanations.

Id. at 62-63, 512 S.E.2d at 502.Â  The trial judge ruled appellant had violated Batson.Â  According to the judge, because appellant exercised all but one of his strikes against prospective white jurors, â€œâ€˜[t]he cumulative effect is a lot worse picture than looking at it on an individual basis.â€™â€Â  Id. at 63, 512 S.E.2d at 503.Â  The trial judge quashed the jury and ordered selection of a new jury.Â  Further, the judge ruled appellant could not strike Juror #126 during the second jury selection. Both Jurors #95 and #126 were seated on the second jury.
On appeal, appellant alleged the judge erred in finding his strikes violated Batson.Â  The supreme court illuminated:

In this case, appellantâ€™s explanations were facially race-neutral.Â  In particular, with regard to Juror #126, an attorneyâ€™s personal knowledge of and relationship with a prospective juror is a race-neutral reason.Â  See State v. Adams, [322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996)] (a potential jurorâ€™s acquaintance with the trial judge is a valid reason for exercising a peremptory strike).Â  With regard to Juror #95, a prospective jurorâ€™s employment in a hardware store owned by a longtime magistrate where local law enforcement officials gather is a race-neutral reason.Â  State v. Adams, supra (a potential jurorâ€™s employment as a court reporter is a valid reason for exercising a peremptory strike); State v. Green, [306 S.C. 94, 409 S.E.2d 785 (1991)] (unemployment is a race-neutral reason).Â  Further, it is legitimate to strike potential jurors because of their employment. Â State v. Adams, supra; State v. Green, supra.Â  Also, it is legitimate to strike a potential juror because she or he has a relationship with a law enforcement official or because she or he is pro-law enforcement.Â  Compare with State v. Richburg, 304 S.C. 162, 403 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (Stateâ€™s explanation that juror was anti-law enforcement was race-neutral).
Further, these explanations are not so fundamentally implausible as to constitute mere pretext without some showing of disparate treatment.Â  The State offered no evidence of pretext, as required by step three of the Adams/Purkett analysis.Â  Although appellant exercised most of his strikes against white jurors, he did not strike every white juror.Â  Instead, some white jurors were accepted by appellant and were placed on the first jury.Â  Further, the fact that appellant used most of his challenges to strike white jurors is not sufficient, in itself, to establish purposeful discrimination.Â  See State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 512 S.E.2d 99 (1998) (no Batson violation where the State exercised all six of its peremptory strikes against blacks because the explanations were race-neutral); State v. Casey, 325 S.C. 447, 481 S.E.2d 169 (Ct. App. 1997) (no Batson violation where solicitor had neutral reasons for all five strikes used against males).Â  Thus, this record fails to support the trial judgeâ€™s finding of a Batson violation.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge erred in ruling these strikes violated Batson, and appellant was denied his right to exercise his peremptory challenges.

Id. at 65-66, 512 S.E.2d at 503-04.
In State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 515 S.E.2d 88 (1999), the jurors seated in appellantâ€™s case included three white men, five white women, one black man, and three black women.Â  The two alternate jurors, who did not participate in deliberations, were black men.Â  The prosecutor exercised peremptory challenges against four black women and one white man.Â  Appellant is a black man.Â  Appellant raised a Batson challenge to the prosecutorâ€™s decision to strike the black women as prospective jurors.Â  The prosecutor stated he struck the first black woman because she was very young and had gone to school with appellant.Â  He struck the second black woman because she had a shoplifting conviction.Â  He struck the fourth black woman because she was unemployed, which meant she had an insufficient stake in the community.Â  The trial judge ruled all those were race-neutral reasons for the
strikes. The prosecutor declared he struck the third black woman, Tammy Berry, for two reasons: â€œOne reason is that she had prior jury service on a criminal sexual conduct and came back with a not guilty verdict.Â  That wasnâ€™t the main reason.Â  The main reason was that Larry Smith who is a key witness here knows this person, says she is a good person but she is very high strung, a critical type person, opinionated and he didnâ€™t feel like she could deliberate well with the other jurors, would be a polarizing individual.â€Â  Id. at 627, 515 S.E.2d at 90 (footnote omitted).
Appellant argued the first reason given by the prosecutor was pretextual because the prosecutor had accepted Gerald Smith, a white man, who also had returned a not guilty verdict in a criminal case.Â  Smith had sat on a criminal jury eighteen to twenty years earlier, and he thought he remembered that the verdict in the domestic shooting case was not guilty.Â  Berry had sat on a criminal jury five years earlier, and definitely remembered that the verdict in the rape case was not guilty.Â  Appellant argued the second reason given by the prosecutor was pretextual because Berry did not stand up during voir dire to say she knew Larry Williams when venire members were asked whether they knew law enforcement officers involved in the case.Â  The trial judge denied the Batson motion, ruling both the prosecutorâ€™s reasons were racially neutral and not pretextual.
On appeal, the supreme court concluded appellant did not carry his burden in proving the prosecutor engaged in purposeful discrimination during the jury selection process.Â  The court found:

[T]he prosecutorâ€™s primary reason for striking Berry was because the lead detective in appellantâ€™s case knew her to be a high-strung, critical person who would be a polarizing force on the jury.Â  That was a race-neutral reason for the strike.Â  Cf. State v. Richburg, 304 S.C. 162, 403 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (officerâ€™s apparent knowledge that venireperson had anti-law enforcement bias may be race-neutral reason for strike); State v. Smith, 321 S.C. 471, 469 S.E.2d 57 (Ct. App. 1996) (trooperâ€™s personal contact with venirepersons and belief they may hold anti-law enforcement bias may be race-neutral reason for strike).Â  Berryâ€™s failure to reveal during voir dire that she was acquainted with the lead detective is irrelevant to the Batson analysis, which focuses upon a partyâ€™s knowledge of a potential juror and reason for exercising a peremptory challenge.
. . . .
. . . [W]e do not believe the prosecutorâ€™s second reason was fundamentally implausible or pretextual.Â  First, Berry and Smith were not similarly situated in that Berry had served on a criminal jury five years earlier and definitely remembered the verdict, while Smith had served on a criminal jury some twenty years earlier and was unsure of the verdict.Â  Second, and more importantly, the circumstances of the jury selection process indicate the prosecutor did not strike potential jurors for racially motivated reasons.Â  While the prosecutor struck four black prospective jurors, he seated four black people on the regular jury and two black alternate jurors.Â  See State v. Dyar, [317 S.C. 77, 452 S.E.2d 603 (1994)] (composition of jury panel is one factor to consider in Batson analysis); State v. Guess, 318 S.C. 269, 457 S.E.2d 6 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding no purposeful discrimination, in part because jury included six members of the minority allegedly offended); State v. Watts, 320 S.C. 377, 465 S.E.2d 359 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding no purposeful discrimination, in part because jury was composed of eight white people and four black people, and prosecutor had struck two white people).
Similarly, the record contains no indication the prosecutorâ€™s stated reasons for striking the other three black womenâ€”that one was too young and knew appellant, one had a criminal conviction, and one was unemployedâ€”were motivated by purposeful discrimination.Â  See State v. Ford, [334 S.C. 59, 512 S.E.2d 500 (1999)] (lack of employment or place or type of employment may be race-neutral reason for strike); State v. Johnson, 302 S.C. 243, 395 S.E.2d 167 (1990) (potential jurorâ€™s knowledge of and association with defendant may be race-neutral reason for strike); State v. Dyar, supra (past prosecution of potential juror by particular solicitorâ€™s office may be race-neutral reason for strike); State v. Green, 306 S.C. 94, 409 S.E.2d 785 (1991) (unemployment may be race-neutral reason for a strike); State v. Martinez, 294 S.C. 72, 362 S.E.2d 641 (1987) (unemployment and possible criminal records may be race-neutral reasons for a strike).

Id. at 630-32, 515 S.E.2d at 91.
In State v. Smalls, 336 S.C. 301, 519 S.E.2d 793 (Ct. App. 1999), the appellant used nine of ten peremptory strikes to remove white jurors from the venire.Â  The State posited a Batson objection, alleging the defense utilized the strikes in an intentionally discriminatory manner.Â  The trial court then asked defense counsel to give race-neutral reasons for the strikes, to which she responded, â€œA lot of this was just looking at the potential jurors and seeingâ€”if they donâ€™t look at me or if they look with a mean, stern look.â€Â  Id. at 304, 519 S.E.2d at 794.Â  She further explained that she believed those persons who tended to look away or glare were not open-minded, and stated that such veniremen â€œhave already made their minds up, and I donâ€™t want them on the jury.â€Â  Id.Â  While the trial judge admitted counselâ€™s stated explanation â€œpossibly could be reasonable,â€ he determined it was not sufficiently race-neutral.Â  Id.Â  As a result, the court returned the jury panel to the pool, and a new jury was drawn and sworn.Â  The new panel contained four members originally struck by the defense.
On appeal, the court of appeals determined:

We discern no discriminatory intent inherent in the defendantâ€™s explanation.Â  We therefore find the reason asserted by Smalls for his peremptory strikes, that the jurors were either refusing to look or looking in a â€œmean,â€ â€œsternâ€ or â€œaccusatoryâ€ manner, was facially race-neutral, even if perhaps suspect.Â  See State v. Tucker, [334 S.C. 1, 512 S.E.2d 99 (1999)]; State v. Wilder, 306 S.C. 535, 413 S.E.2d 323 (1991) (counsel may strike venire persons based on their demeanor and disposition).Â  The trial court erred, therefore, in failing to require the State to carry its burden to present evidence of pretext as prescribed by step three of the Adams/Purkett analysis.Â  See Ford at 66, 512 S.E.2d at 504 (finding opponent of strikes failed to offer evidence of pretext as required by step three of the analysis); Adams, 322 S.C. at 124, 470 S.E.2d at 372 (stating that â€œ[u]nder some circumstances, the race-neutral explanation given by the proponent may be so fundamentally implausible that the judge may determine, at the third step of the analysis, that the explanation was mere pretextâ€) (emphasis added); Purkett, 514 U.S. at 768, 115 S.Ct. at 1771 (opponent of strike bears ultimate burden of persuasion regarding racial motivation); cf. Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. at 55-56, 495 S.E.2d at 208 (â€œredneckâ€ is not race-neutral on its face so there is no need to reach the third step of the analysis).

Id. at 309, 519 S.E.2d at 797.
In State v. Wright, 354 S.C. 48, 579 S.E.2d 538 (Ct. App. 2003), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005), the State exercised peremptory challenges to strike three black jurors.Â  Wright objected and requested a Batson hearing.Â  Specifically, as to Juror 29, the State explained that although she was a bilingual translator, she had a heavy accent, and the State was unsure as to her command of the English language.Â  Wright then responded the State did not strike Juror 123, a white German woman who had a â€œhuge accent.â€Â  Id. at 51, 579 S.E.2d at 540.Â  The State countered that it was under the impression Juror 123 worked in communications at the fire department and would thus have a better grasp of the English language.Â  Based on this dialogue, the circuit court found the Stateâ€™s peremptory strike did not violate Batson, and the jury was seated and sworn.
On appeal, Wright claimed the circuit court erred by allowing the State to exercise peremptory challenges in a racially discriminatory manner in violation of Batson.Â  The court of appeals held:

Viewing the record in light of our standard of review, the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion was not clearly erroneous.Â  Although we recognize Juror 29 and Juror 123 are similarly situated in that they both have foreign accents, the State distinguished them by their observable command of the English language, as well as what the State perceived their occupations to be.Â  These were proper race-neutral considerations.Â  See Matthews v. Evatt, 105 F.3d 907, 918 (4th Cir. 1997) (holding the State is allowed to consider tone, demeanor, facial expression, and any other race-neutral factors when striking jurors).Â  Thus, the circuit court did not err.

Id. at 56, 579 S.E.2d at 542.
In State v. Flynn, Op. No. 4087 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 27, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 9 at 48), after the jury was qualified, defense counsel raised a Batson challenge based on the fact that the State used all its strikes to remove black females from the jury.Â  The State presented its explanations for the strikes.Â  As to Juror 21, the State asserted: â€œâ€˜[She] is a Head Start director. I view that as a very liberal job and thatâ€™s the reason why I struck her.â€™â€Â  Id. at 49.Â  Defense counsel took exception to the Stateâ€™s reasons for striking Juror 21. The State then expounded on its reasons for striking her: â€œâ€˜Your Honor, I believe that is a social welfare kind of program, and as director she is liberal in nature. Itâ€™s a liberal type of attitude and job, and that is why I struck her.â€™â€Â  Id. at 50.Â  The trial court ruled that, given the nature of the case and progress of the trial to that point, it would be possible to consider a Head Start director as an improper juror.Â  The court stated: â€œâ€˜Iâ€™m going to conclude that itâ€™s race neutral, particularly in view of the fact that the Defendant is a young white Caucasian. That particular juror is female, African-American. I conclude thatâ€™s race-neutral.â€™â€Â  Id. at 50.
On appeal, Flynn argued the trial court erred in not finding the State violated Batson in regard to its treatment of Juror 21. He asserts the State advanced a racial stereotype to justify striking Juror 21.Â  The court of appeals determined: â€œ[T]he State asserted that due to her employment, it believed Juror 21 was â€˜liberal.â€™ As Flynn has offered no evidence other than a conclusory assertion of racial motivation, we find the trial court did not err in failing to find a Batson violation.â€Â  Id. at 51.
VI.Â  Batson Violation/Remedy
Any deviation from the mandated and recognized Batson procedure is NOT a mere peccadillo, but is an egregious judicial corrigendum.Â  Notwithstanding error, the more pertinent query is whether reversal is obligatory.
 State v. Adams edifies in regard to the remedy for a Batson violation:

Nevertheless, we do not reverse based on this error. We have not yet ruled on the proper remedy for a trial judgeâ€™s error in finding a Batson violation and quashing the jury.Â  This situation is fundamentally different from one in which the trial judge improperly upholds racially discriminatory peremptory challenges. When the trial court improperly upholds
such challenges, there has been a violation of the stricken jurorsâ€™ Fourteenth Amendment equal protection rights. Additionally, if the prosecution is the party improperly exercising peremptory challenges that the trial judge upholds, the defendant has been denied a right to a fair and impartial jury of his peers.
  However, where, as here, the trial judge improperly quashes a jury panel, no jurorâ€™s equal protection rights have been violated. An appellate determination that a judge erred in finding a Batson violation means the obvious: No Batson violation occurred, and there was, therefore, no denial of anyoneâ€™s equal protection rights. Moreover, we see no way in which the defendantâ€™s fair trial rights were violated.Â  A defendant has no right to trial by any particular jury.Â  E.g., State v. Caldwell, 300 S.C. 494, 388 S.E.2d 816 (1990). When the trial judge quashed the first jury panel, the parties selected a new jury.Â  Adams has voiced no complaints about the new jury.Â  We find that no prejudice resulted from the judgeâ€™s error.

Id. at 125-26, 470 S.E.2d at 372-73.
Unlike in Adams, the Appellants in the instant case have complained about the new jury.
In State v. Short, 333 S.C. 473, 511 S.E.2d 358 (1999), after ruling the trial court erred in finding a Batson violation and quashing the first jury, the supreme court inculcated:

After finding error in the trial judgeâ€™s Batson ruling, the Court of Appeals went on to find reversible error because Shortâ€™s right to exercise peremptory challenges against the two jurors was denied him.Â  The Court of Appeals found no showing of prejudice was required because there was no way to determine with any degree of certainty whether Shortâ€™s right to a fair trial by an impartial jury was abridged.Â  327 S.C. at 335, 489 S.E.2d at 212.
In finding reversible error, the Court of Appeals adopted the analysis of United States v. Annigoni, 96 F.3d 1132 (9th Cir. 1996), requiring no showing of actual prejudice to reverse for infringement of the federal statutory right to exercise a peremptory challenge.Â  This rule is consistent with that of a clear majority of state courts as well.Â  See, e.g., Mason v. State, 536 So. 2d 127 (Ala. Crim. App. 1988); State v. Huerta, 175 Ariz. 262, 855 P.2d 776 (1993); Hagerman v. State, 613 So. 2d 552 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1993); People v. Bennett, 282 Ill.App.3d 975, 218 Ill.Dec. 574, 669 N.E.2d 717 (1996); State v. Kauhi, 86 Hawaiâ€™i 195, 948 P.2d 1036 (1997); Spencer v. State, 20 Md.App. 201, 314 A.2d 727 (1974); Commonwealth v. Roche, 44 Mass.App. 372, 691 N.E.2d 946 (1998); People v. Schmitz, 231 Mich.App. 521, 586 N.W.2d 766 (1998); Arenas v. Gari, 309 N.J.Super. 1, 706 A.2d 736 (1998); Fuson v. State, 105 N.M. 632, 735 P.2d 1138 (1987); City of Dickinson v. Lindstrom, 575 N.W.2d 440 (N.D. 1998); Baker v. English, 324 Or. 585, 932 P.2d 57 (1997); Commonwealth v. Ingber, 516 Pa. 2, 531 A.2d 1101 (1987); Nunfio v. State, 808 S.W.2d 482 (Tex. Crim. App. 1991); State v. Ramos, 211 Wis.2d 12, 564 N.W.2d 328 (1997); Westcom v. Meunier, 164 Vt. 536, 674 A.2d 1267 (1996); Wardell v. McMillan, 844 P.2d 1052 (Wyo. 1992).
To the contrary, however, there is precedent of this Court indicating a showing of actual prejudice is required to find reversible error in the denial of the right to exercise a peremptory challenge.Â  In State v. Plath, 277 S.C. 126, 284 S.E.2d 221 (1981), overruled on other grounds, State v. Collins, 329 S.C. 23, 495 S.E.2d 202 (1998), we concluded the defendant failed to show prejudice from the denial of a peremptory challenge where there was ample opportunity to examine the juror on voir dire and there was no showing of any bias or lack of impartiality on the part of the juror.Â  Accordingly, we found no reversible error.
We now overrule Plath and adopt the majority rule that no showing of actual prejudice is required to find reversible error for the denial or impairment of the right to a peremptory challenge.Â  We note that Plath is distinguishable from our other decisions discussing â€œprejudiceâ€ in the denial of a peremptory challenge where the issue actually turned on whether the complaining party had established he was denied the right to exercise a peremptory challenge.Â  Where such a denial was established, we implicitly applied the majority rule discussed above and reversed without a showing of actual prejudice.Â  See State v. Anderson, 276 S.C. 578, 281 S.E.2d 111 (1981) (prejudice in wrongfully limiting number of peremptory challenges where defendant exercised all permitted); Moore v. Jenkins, 304 S.C. 544, 405 S.E.2d 833 (1991) (failure to use side-to-side procedure in allowing peremptory challenges in a case with multiple defendants prejudiced the plaintiff as a matter of law).Â  In cases finding no prejudice, on the other hand, we actually determined the complaining party had not established the denial of a peremptory challenge.Â  See Laury v. Hamilton, 317 S.C. 503, 455 S.E.2d 173 (1995) (no prejudice where party received greater number of strikes than that to which he was entitled under side-to-side method); State v. Holland, 261 S.C. 488, 201 S.E.2d 118 (1973) (no prejudice in limiting number of peremptory challenges where defendants used fewer than allowed).Â  Before reversible error can be found, the complaining party must of course establish the denial of his right to exercise a peremptory challenge.

Short, 333 S.C. at 476-78, 511 S.E.2d at 360-61 (footnote omitted).
Thereafter, in State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 512 S.E.2d 500 (1999), the supreme court explicated:

The State argues, even if the trial judge erred in finding a Batson violation, the error was harmless because appellant failed to show the second jury was not impartial.Â  This Court recently addressed this precise issue.Â  See State v. Short, 333 S.C. 473, 511 S.E.2d 358 (1999) (announcing the appropriate remedy for the denial of the right to exercise a peremptory challenge).Â  Where such a denial is established, no showing of actual prejudice is required to find reversible error.Â  Id. Â Therefore, because appellant established he was wrongfully denied the right to exercise a peremptory challenge, we reverse his conviction.

Id. at 66, 512 S.E.2d at 504; see also State v. Smalls, 336 S.C. 301, 309, 519 S.E.2d 793, 797 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œno showing of actual prejudice is required to find reversible error for the denial or impairment of the right to a peremptory challenge.â€); cf. State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 444, 513 S.E.2d 385 (Ct. App. 1999) (noting that any Batson violation in regards to a possible alternate juror is harmless where an alternate was not needed for deliberations).

 State v. Rayfield, 357 S.C. 497, 593 S.E.2d 486 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (March 3, 2005), is instructive.Â  After the initial jury selection, the State moved for a Batson hearing.Â  The trial court found a Batson violation.Â  The first jury was quashed and a redraw of the jury followed.Â  The ensuing redraw resulted in no Batson challenge, and significantly, none of the jurors struck by defense counsel during the initial jury selection were seated on the second jury.Â  On appeal, Rayfield argued the trial court erred in granting the Stateâ€™s Batson motion.Â  The court of appeals held:
We agree, but we are constrained to conclude that Rayfield ultimately was not legally prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s error.
. . . .
. . . It was error for the trial court to grant the Stateâ€™s Batson motion.
We nevertheless find no reversible error pursuant to the supreme court precedent of State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996).Â  In Adams, the trial court erred in granting the Stateâ€™s Batson motion and quashing the jury.Â  Because the jury ultimately selected had none of the persons defense counsel struck from the first jury panel, the supreme court found â€œno prejudice resulted from the judgeâ€™s errorâ€ and affirmed Adamsâ€™ convictions.Â  Id. at 126, 470 S.E.2d at 373.Â  In so holding, the court in Adams recognized that no jurorâ€™s equal protection rights are violated where the trial court improperly quashes a jury panel.Â  In addition, the court in Adams referenced the settled principle that â€œ[a] defendant has no right to trial by any particular jury.â€Â  Id. Â But cf. Ford, 334 S.C. at 66, 512 S.E.2d at 504 (holding that reversal and granting of a new trial is a proper remedy where the trial court erred in finding defendant violated Batson in striking certain jurors and any challenged juror was seated on the second jury).

Id. at 500-04, 593 S.E.2d at 488-90.
VII.Â  The Extant Record
Analyzing the first jury and the composition and pattern of strikes, I come to the ineluctable conclusion that the trial judge did not properly conduct the Batson hearing.Â  The erroneous procedure utilized in the first Batson hearing was exacerbated in the selection of the second jury, thereby mandating a reversal.
The record is devoid of any palliative factor mitigating against reversal.
I VOTE to REVERSE.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Appellant Reggie James was also found guilty of malicious injury to personal property; however, after the verdict, and despite appropriate motions made during the course of the trial, the trial court decided to revisit this issue and found â€œno testimonyâ€ of vandalism.Â  Accordingly, the court directed a verdict of acquittal as to this charge.
[2]Â  Â Â Â Â Â  A defendant charged with burglary is entitled to ten peremptory challenges and the State is entitled to five.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1110 (Supp. 2005).Â  Codefendants, tried jointly, are entitled to twenty peremptory challenges.Â  Id.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  See also J.E.B. v. Alabama ex rel. T. B., 511 U.S. 127, 146 (1994) (recognizing the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a juror on the basis of gender).Â Â  
[4]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We do not suggest that counselâ€™s perception of the Patrick Henry School has any validity.Â  Perceptions and perceived biasesâ€”whether true or notâ€”are at the heart of virtually every peremptory challenge.Â  The striking of a juror based on perceptions of bias will generally be upheld unless it is established that the reason for the strike is impermissibly based on race or gender.Â  The Batson burden of proof framework as set forth in Pukett-AdamsÂ  seeks to achieve a proper balance between a partyâ€™s ability to peremptorily strike a potential juror while allowing the opponent of the strike to prove purposeful racial or gender discrimination. 
[5] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Although we need not find prejudice to reverse this error, prejudice may be found in juryâ€™s guilty verdict against Appellant James for the offense of malicious injury to personal property.Â  The trial court set aside the guilty verdict, finding â€œno testimonyâ€ of vandalism.
